  • Allows for a voter registration to be canceled if the voters registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections, and establishes certain reporting requirements.  
  • Outlines certain procedures and rules for the state registrar to conduct an audit. 
  • Allows the state commissioner or their designee to oversee activities of county election commissioners under certain circumstances, defining "oversee." 
  • Specifies a person serving on a precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of an election will be immediately removed from the board. 
  • Allows a voter to choose anyone to assist them in voting, except someone whose name is on the ballot. 
  • Prohibits an election official or county commissioner from obstructing or interfering with a person's role or duty and specifies penalties. 
  • Allows members of law enforcement to take "all reasonable actions" to prevent election violations. 
  • Allows voters to apply for absentee ballots no more than 70 days before the election and specifies when a commissioner may not send an absentee ballot, and in the event of a public health disaster allows the general assembly to require the state commissioner to send an absentee ballot application to each registered voter. 
  • Specifies that absentee ballot applications may not have prefilled fields, except type and date of election. 
  • Specifies requirements for commissioners in handling absentee ballot applications arriving at certain times, and specifies reporting requirements for absentee ballots. 
  • Specifies timelines for mailing out absentee ballots.
  • Requires information to the voter that an absentee ballot may be returned to certain drop boxes under certain conditions. 
  • Prohibits election officials from mailing an absentee ballot to anyone not submitting an application. 
  • Requires a commissioner to provide absentee in-person voting no more than 18 days before an election, and to create satellite absentee voting stations when receiving a petition meeting certain requirements. 
  • Removes the postmark requirement for return absentee envelopes and relies on a postal service barcode instead. 
  • Outlines requirements for handling return absentee envelopes including drop box requirements, deadlines, security, accessibility, retrieval of ballots, and processing. 
  • Defines relevant terms. 
  • Specifies processes for voter affidavits lacking specific requirements and outlines requirements. 
  • Specifies information required for record keeping of absentee ballots by the commissioner. 
  • Outlines requirements for if a voter is hospitalized after the deadline for a written application for an absentee ballot and how to return the ballot. 
  • Specifies requirements for handling, recording, and reporting on signed affidavits and reconciling them with the number of ballots counted. 
  • Outlines who may return a completed absentee ballot. 
  • Clarifies that an appointed or elective officer may be removed by impeachment for failure to pay a fine. 
  • Requires vacancy appointments by the board of supervisors be until the next general elections and requires if a petition is circulated and filed within 14 days of the publication only to be valid of the signature is dated prior to the date the appointment was made. 
  • Removes the provision that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election. 
  • Provides for the county attorney bringing action for failure to pay fines.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including absentee ballots and voter list maintenance activities, making penalties applicable, and including effective date provisions.(See SF 413.)
most_recent_action: Committee report approving bill, renumbered as SF 413.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Oversight and accountability,Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Election dates and administrative deadlines,Enforcement against officials,Election officials,Legal causes of action,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Ballot collection
summary:
This bill adds ways election officials can fail in their duties including disregarding or hindering the law and inadequate voter list maintenance. This bill prohibits election officials serving as a member of the challenging committee while also serving as a precinct official at the polls, making it a third degree misconduct charge. This bill also makes interfering with a person permitted at a polling place a third degree misconduct charge. This bill classifies the following as election misconduct: return of an absentee ballot to a drop box by a person prohibited from collecting and delivering completed absentee ballots, and making a false statement reporting that an absentee ballot was returned to a drop box by a person prohibited from delivering ballots. This bill required that a state commissioner impose a fine of $10,000 or less upon a technical infraction by a county commissioner and outlines the process of paying the fine and possible suspension. This bill requires the state commissioner to immediately inform the attorney general and relevant county attorney if a technical infraction may constitute election misconduct. This bill requires the attorney general to investigate allegations of election misconduct reported to him or her, or to the county attorney and requires certain related actions. This bill requires nomination papers in partisan nominations be signed by eligible electors. 

This bill requires nonparty political organizations to have a minimum of 500 eligible electors at its convention or caucus to nominate candidates for statewide office, 200 eligible electors for US representative, 20 eligible electors for county or city office, 25 eligible electors for representative in the general assembly, and 50 eligible electors for a state senatorial district. This bill also states a candidate who has been nominated under a political party is not eligible for a nonparty nomination for the same office in the same election year. This bill requires nomination petitions for candidates for US Senator, President, Vice President, Governor, and Lieutenant Governor be signed by at least 3,500 eligible voters with at least 100 of the voters coming from at least 19 counties. This bill also states that nomination petitions for other statewide offices must be signed by at least 2,500 eligible voters including at least 77 from at least 18 counties. This bill requires nomination petitions for US House of Representatives be signed by at least 1,726 eligible voters with at least 47 voters from at least one-half of the counties in the district. This bill further makes changes to the number of signatories on nomination petitions for county-wide office, county supervisor, city offices, and special charter city offices. 

This bill allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance to clarify election laws. This bill clarifies that the county commissioner of elections doe not have home rule powers related to the conduct of elections. This bill outlines quarterly voter verification, reporting, and report publication requirements for the state registrar and allows the registrar to pursue related third party vendor contracts. This bill also requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center to update voter information. This bill requires each commissioner to update registration information using specific guidelines, and follow specific reporting requirements. This bill allows for a voter registration to be canceled if the voters registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections. This bill provides for electronic records to include a status code designating whether records are active and specifies actions to be taken for inactive records. This bill outlines certain procedures and rules for the state registrar to conduct an audit. This bill allows the state commissioner or their designee to oversee activities of county election commissioners under certain circumstances, defining "oversee." This bill specifies a person serving on a precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of an election will be immediately removed from the board. This bill specifies that a voter may choose anyone to assist them in voting, except someone whose name is on the ballot. This bill prohibits an election official or county commissioner from obstructing or interfering with a person's role or duty and specifies penalties. This bill allows members of law enforcement to take "all reasonable actions" to prevent election violations. This bill allows voters to apply for absentee ballots no more than 70 days before the election and specifies when a commissioner may not sent an absentee ballot. This bill specifies that absentee ballot applications may not have prefilled fields, except type and date of election. This bill specifies requirements for commissioners in handling absentee ballot applications arriving at certain times, and specifies reporting requirements for absentee ballots. This bill specifies that absentee ballots must include a statement that they may be returned to certain drop boxes under certain conditions. This bill prohibits election officials from mailing an absentee ballot to anyone not submitting an application. This bill requires a commissioner to provide absentee in-person voting no more than 18 days before an election, and to create satellite absentee voting stations when receiving a petition meeting certain requirements. This bill removes the postmark requirement for return absentee envelopes and relies on a postal service barcode. This bill outlines requirements for handling return absentee envelopes including drop box requirements, deadlines, security, accessibility, retrieval of ballots, and processing. This bill defines relevant terms. This bill specifies processes for voter affidavits lacking specific requirements and outlines requirements. This bill specifies information required for record keeping of absentee ballots by the commissioner. This bill specifies requirements for if a voter is hospitalized after the deadline for a written application for an absentee ballot and how to return the ballot. This bill specifies requirements for handling, recording, and reporting on signed affidavits and reconciling them with the number of ballots counted. This bill specifies who may return a completed absentee ballot. This bill specifies that an appointed or elective officer may be removed by impeachment for failure to pay a fine. This bill requires vacancy appointments by the board of supervisors be until the next general elections and requires if a petition is circulated and filed within 14 days of the publication only to be valid of the signature is dated prior to the date the appointment was made. This bill removes the provision that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election. This bill provides for the county attorney bringing action for failure to pay fines.

name: Adds to existing law to require notification of boundary changes for election zones, districts, and subdistricts.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 25, 2022 Session Law Chapter 257 Effective: 07/01/2022
summary: • Requires a city or district with governing members elected by separate zones, districts, or subdistricts to notify the county clerk within 30 days of approved changes to district boundaries.

name: Adds to existing law to authorize either or both houses of the Legislature to intervene in certain actions regarding constitutionality of an Idaho statute.
summary: • Allows the legislature to intervene when a party challenges the constitutionality of an Idaho statute by serving a motion upon the parties.

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide that a person's residence for voting purposes shall be the homestead for which the person claims a certain tax exemption and to provide for an investigation into candidate qualifications.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 21, 2022 Session Law Chapter 81 Effective: 03/21/2022
summary:
• Specifies procedures for if a voter claims a homestead exemption.
  • Provides provisions for investigating a candidates qualification for office.
  • Requires a declaration of candidacy include a sworn verification that the candidate satisfies legal qualifications for office, including disclosure of the homestead exemption.
  • Requires the state tax commission to disclose information about an improper claim for homestead exemption to the county clerk and secretary of state, who are to use it to determine a person's voting residence. 
  • Requires the state tax commission to establish a searchable database of active homestead exemptions accessible to relevant officials.

name: Adds to and amends existing law to allow the Secretary of State or a county clerk to petition for judicial review of an election when it appears that an error occurred in the administration of the election and the error might be sufficient to change the outcome of the election.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 18, 2022 Session Law Chapter Effective:
summary:
• Outlines a procedure for judicial review of election results, including timetable and notifications.
  • Outlines district court roles and powers in the case of juridical review of an election.

name: Amends, repeals, and adds to existing law to revise provisions regarding voter identification.
most_recent_action: Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Outlines acceptable forms of identification for registering to vote, including for proof of identity and proof of citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain a voter registration website.
  • Specifies requirements for verification of online and mailed registration in certain circumstances.
  • Specifies individuals using the federal voter registration form, not providing identification required by Idaho law, will only be eligible to vote for federal office.
  • Specifies required information for a voter registration oath or affirmation.
  • Creates and funds an election integrity fund.
  • Specifies that certain code must be followed regarding acceptable personal identification at the polls.
  • Specifies all records to be retained for five years after an election.
  • Requires voter registration through the department of motor vehicles include proof of citizenship.
  • Requires drivers licenses or identification cards of US citizens have a notation "USA" included on the license.
  • Requires the motor vehicle department to keep records of the proof relied upon to determine citizenship status of an applicant.
  • Requires the motor vehicles department to issue a free identification card under certain circumstances and requires the applicant to submit proof of citizenship, identity, and date of birth.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding voter identification and registration.
most_recent_action: Senate State Affairs Committee (08:00 3/11/2022 Room WW55)
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Requires proof of US citizenship when registering to vote.
  • Outlines provisions for individuals who cannot provide proof of identity, residence, or citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain an electronic system for voter registration and includes proof of US citizenship in required documents.
  • Requires those registering electronically, or by mail, to vote in-person at least once before being able to vote absentee, with certain exceptions.
  • Outlines required identification for mail-in registration and registration applications.
  • Removes provisions related to unaffiliated party affiliation.
  • Outlines certain requirements for absentee ballot applications.
  • Removes the possibility of electronic transmission of completed absentee ballots.
  • Outlines content requirements for the absentee ballot return envelope.
  • Requires the absentee ballot be returned by mail or delivered personally by hand.
  • Aligns rules regarding voter identification at the polls.
  • Requires a voter without proper identification to complete an affidavit on a secure envelope, place his or her ballot in the envelope, and return to the polling place within two business days with proper identification. 
  • Provides instructions to the clerk in the case of a provisional ballot.



  • Removes provisions related to voter registration including where a registration may be delivered and provisions related to unaffiliated voter registration and voting.
  •  and includes a list of acceptable forms of identification when registering.
  • Provides that a first time voter registrant using the federal application form who did not provide voter identification required by Idaho law will only be eligible to vote in federal races.
  • Includes all information required under oath for voter registration.
  • Provides for a provisional ballot when a voter lacks proper identification and outlines administrative actions to be taken with the provisional ballot.
  • Removes student identification cards as acceptable identification at the polls. 
  • Requires certain county records be maintain for five years, adding provisional ballot envelopes to the list.
  • Removes election day registration from early absentee voting rules.

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide for postelection audits of selected paper ballots in certain elections by the Secretary of State.
summary:
• Specifies that stored ballots may be unsealed and resealed as part of a post election audit.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to identify and order a post election audit of certain paper ballots cast in any election, with notification requirements.
  • Specifies procedures related to the post election audit.
  • Specifies which elections may be audited and how precincts may be chosen for audit. 
  • Allows the Secretary of State to select certain ballots from early and absentee ballot voting for an audit.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to conduct the audit and requires the county clerk to facilitate it.
  • Specifies procedures for the audit, including who may attend it, the timetable, notifications, observers, reporting, costs and payment, and follow up.

name: Adds to existing law to provide for absentee ballot assistance at certain facilities and to prohibit certain actions.
most_recent_action: House State Affairs Committee (09:00 3/11/2022 Room EW40)
summary:
• Outlines procedures for providing assistance to voters in certain facilities when assistance is requested for absentee voting, including training, personnel, and who may assist a voter.
  • Specifies that attempting to influence a voter when providing absentee ballot assistance is a misdemeanor crime.

name: Amends and adds to existing law to revise provisions regarding identification for voter registration and voting purposes.
most_recent_action: U.C. to be returned to State Affairs Committee
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration
summary:
• Amends which records need to be kept for five years after an election.
  • Lists approved identification for election day registration, including providing proof of US citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain a voter registration website.
  • Stipulates rules for verification for uniformed and overseas citizens voting absentee.
  • Stipulates requirements for mail in registration identification.
  • Specifies individuals using the federal voter registration form, not providing identification required by Idaho law, will only be eligible to vote for federal office.
  • Specifies required information for a voter registration oath or affirmation.
  • Establishes and funds an election integrity fund.
  • Stipulates required forms of identification at the polls.
  • Requires voter registration through the department of motor vehicles include proof of citizenship.
  • Requires drivers licenses or identification cards of US citizens have a notation "USA" included on the license.
  • Requires the motor vehicle department to keep records of the proof relied upon to determine citizenship status of an applicant.
  • Requires the motor vehicles department to issue a free identification card under certain circumstances and requires the applicant to submit proof of citizenship, identity, and date of birth.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding the deadline to change political party affiliation or unaffiliated designation.
most_recent_action: Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs
summary: • Removes provisions for affiliating with a party as an unaffiliated elector.

name: Amends existing law to provide for the filling of certain school board trustee vacancies.
most_recent_action: Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing
summary:
• Directs that the term of incumbent trustees elected as of July 1, 2018 will expire January 1 following the November election.
  • Requires the election date for the recall of a school district trustee follow Idaho Code.
  • Outlines procedures, including timelines, for filling a vacancy or vacancies on the school board of trustees, including possibly appointing temporary trustees.

name: Amends, repeals, and adds to existing law to revise provisions regarding voter identification to register to vote and to cast ballots.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter participation deadlines,Provisional ballots,Voter registration
summary:
• Removes provisions related to voter registration including where a registration may be delivered and provisions related to unaffiliated voter registration and voting.
  • Requires proof of US citizenship when registering to vote and includes a list of acceptable forms of identification when registering.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain an electronic system for voter registration and provides instructions for verifying a current address for electronic submissions.
  • Provides that a first time voter registrant using the federal application form who did not provide voter identification required by Idaho law will only be eligible to vote in federal races.
  • Includes all information required under oath for voter registration.
  • Provides for a provisional ballot when a voter lacks proper identification and outlines administrative actions to be taken with the provisional ballot.
  • Removes student identification cards as acceptable identification at the polls. 
  • Requires certain county records be maintain for five years, adding provisional ballot envelopes to the list.
  • Removes election day registration from early absentee voting rules.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding the sealing and storage of ballots in the event of a challenge, recount, or contest.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to Ways & Means
summary: • Allows stored ballots to be unsealed by order of Secretary of State or the county clerk when there is a challenge by a candidate or organization affiliated with a ballot measure, or for a recount.

name: Amends existing law to provide for automatic voter registration through the Division of Motor Vehicles.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to Ways & Means
summary:
• Allows electronic voter registration applications from the transportation department.
  • Requires the transportation department to register each eligible voter who applies for a drivers license or identity card.
  • Requires the drivers license office to forward completed registration applications weekly and on the business day prior to registration closing.
  • Requires the division of motor vehicles to provide for an elector to drop out of registration.

name: Amends, adds to, and repeals existing law to provide for nonpartisan primary elections and ranked-choice voting in general elections.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed; referred to State Affairs
summary:
• Defines terms including "nonpartisan primary election," "precinct captain election," "presidential primary," "ranked choice voting."
  • Outlines the method to be used for ranked choice voting and rules for counting ballots using the method.
  • Removes provisions for unaffiliated voters in primary elections by mail.
  • Requires unaffiliated voters to declare which precinct captain or presidential primary election ballot they wish to vote and aligns relevant rules.
  • Establishes that for nonpartisan primaries, every voter will receive the same ballot.
  • Specifies an elector may change political party affiliation for precinct caption and presidential primary elections within certain guidelines. 
  • Removes certain requirements for write in candidates in nonpartisan primaries.
  • Clarifies that nonpartisan primary elections determine four candidates to appear on the general election ballot, not based upon party.
  • Clarifies that candidates for judicial office will be nominated at the judicial nominating election.
  • Specifies declaration of candidacy rules for nonpartisan primary elections.
  • Specifies with which office each level of candidate needs to file candidacy.
  • Specifies the procedure for notifying parties of declared candidates affiliated with the party.
  • Amends certification of candidate procedures by the Secretary of State. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide a sample form for presidential primaries, nonpartisan primary elections, and precinct captain races to each county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to prepare a sample primary and precinct captain ballot for upcoming elections, including names of all candidates.
  • Specifies procedures and timelines for filling vacancies in nonpartisan primary races and precinct captain elections.
  • Specifies procedures for filling vacancies for nonpartisan judicial races.
  • Amends administrative procedures for withdrawal of candidacy.
  • Requires presidential primary elections to be conducted by laws governing elections for federal office in a general election.
  • Allows candidates for precinct captain to seek one additional office in a nonpartisan primary election.
  • Outlines requirements for primary nonpartisan election ballots and precinct captain election ballots.
  • Adds precinct captain elections to rules for eligibility to vote in presidential primary elections, and rules for absentee ballot applications and issuance of absentee ballots.
  • Outlines rules for what must be printed on ballots for the general election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and disseminate widely voter education materials for nonpartisan primary elections, and general elections at least 60 days before the election.
  • Removes certain requirements on absentee ballot applications related to unaffiliated voters.   
  • Outlines rules and procedures for certificate of nomination for nonpartisan primary elections and precinct captain elections.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding filling vacant school trustee positions following a recall or resignation resulting from a recall petition.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs
summary:
• Requires incumbent trustees elected after July 1, 2018 terms to expire January 1 after the November election.
  • Requires the election date of a recall election for school board trustee to be determined by Idaho Code.
  • Outlines provisions for filling a vacancy in the case of a recall or resignation of a board of trustees member(s), including the timeline and temporary appointments.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Win Stoller
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Adds the Voter Identification Card as an acceptable form of photo ID for voting.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.

name: ELEC CD-DIGITAL SIGN-PETITION
most_recent_action: Chief Sponsor Changed to Sen. Don Harmon
summary:
• Requires the Board to create a downloadable program allowing petition signatures to be collected on electronic devices.
  • Requires the program to be free and made available to all political committees.
  • Sets minimum standards and requirements for the program.
  • Allows the Board to use a third party developer.

name: ELECT CODE-REFERENDA
most_recent_action: Chief Sponsor Changed to Sen. Don Harmon
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to design an alternative signature verification method for petition signatures from state advisory referendums.
  • Removes the requirement that a proponent in a statewide advisory referendum file a copy of the petition with each proper election authority.
  • Allows registered proponents and opponents of proposed amendments to certain articles of the state Constitution to observe the sample signature verification process, and to participate in proceedings related to sample signature verification.
  • Allows political parties and civic organizations to participate in the proceedings related to sample signature verification for proposed amendments to certain articles of the state Constitution.

name: ELECTION CD-VARIOUS PENALTIES
most_recent_action: Chief Sponsor Changed to Sen. Don Harmon
summary:
• Outlines penalties for anyone altering or falsifying information on a report.
  • Defines "public funds."
  • Prohibits the use of public funds to influence a voter regarding a candidate or proposition.
  • Allows the use of public funds for voter information purposes.
  • Outlines penalties for misuse of public funds.
  • Prohibits candidates accepting certain types of contributions and outlines penalties.
  • Prohibits willful failure to file information or falsifying information and outlines penalties.

name: ELEC CODE-REGISTRATION
summary: • Requires a grace period registrant to provide identification with their date of birth.

name: ELEC CD-USE OF FUNDS
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Sue Rezin
summary:
• Defines deep fake videos.
  • Provides that a person is committing a Class A misdemeanor if the person creates, publishes, and distributes a deep fake video with the intent to injure a candidate or influence the results of an election.

name: ELEC CD-REGISTRATION
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Omar Aquino
summary:
• Allows certain forms from the department of motor vehicles to also be used as voter registration applications, provided the applicant presents identification confirming US citizenship and age, unless the applicant denies the option.
  • Provides that if an applicant to the department of motor vehicles does not submit identification confirming US citizenship and does not indicate the applicant is currently registered to vote in the state, then the application will not be a dual-purpose application.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to enter into an agreement with certain agencies for the purpose of updating an applicant's existing voter registration record.
  • Allows the agencies to transmit information about clients who may be registered to vote for the sole purpose of updating their registration.
  • Requires the Department of Healthcare and Family Services to implement automatic voter registration for Medicaid applicants by July 1, 2023.
  • Establishes rules for automatic voter registration applications sent without signature.
  • Establishes procedures for automatic voter registration applications received for individuals protected by certain programs designed for confidentiality of victims.
  • Outlines certain notification requirements for individuals who are automatically registered to vote, including declining to register.
  • Makes other conforming changes to election code.

name: ELEC CD-VARIOUS
most_recent_action: Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Paul Jacobs
categories: Audits,Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Ballot access for candidates,Legal causes of action,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires the posting of uncounted ballot information on a website to also include election judge affidavits.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish training materials and guidelines for judges of elections.
  • Requires the county clerk and the Board of Election Commissioners to incorporate guidelines and training materials from the State Board of Elections, including outlining minimum guidelines.
  • Requires election authorities to automatically register a voter whose information is received through the National Change of Address database within 90 days.
  • Requires the county clerk to conduct a verification of voter registrations after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Allows the county clerk to conduct investigations and conduct canvasses of registered voters after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Provides for the county clerk and the Board of Election Commissioners to certify the verification of information to the State Board of Elections.
  • Allows the Board of Election Commissioners to conduct investigations and make canvasses of registered voters after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Requires that if there is a delay of more than five hours in getting tally sheets to the county clerk, that the two designated judges, one from each major political party, create a written affidavit explaining the delay.
  • Requires the affidavit be delivered to the county clerk and be made available to the general public on a website.
  • Requires vote by mail processing procedures be published on a website at least 120 days before an election.
  • Subjects vote by mail ballots arriving after election day to an audit and outlines the procedures, timeline, and scope of the audit.

name: ELECTIONS-RIGHTS OF VOTERS
summary:
• Establishes that the rights of any citizen to vote may not be abridged due to race, color, or membership in a language minority group.
  • Establishes what constitutes a violation of the right to vote.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to designate a certain locality a language minority area of certain criteria are met.
  • Requires a locality to provide election materials and notices in the applicable language of the language minority group for designated areas, empowering the attorney general or any qualified minority language group member institute a cause of action in the circuit court to compel provision of materials and notices in the minority language. 
  • Outlines related provisions for the action.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Defines "certification of no objection" and defines "covered practices" included in the enfranchisement of minority voters, which include voting and other changes to voting rules.
  • Requires election authorities to publicize proposed changes to covered practices, giving two options, following certain guidelines and outlining the process of challenging proposed changes.
  • Prohibits an at-large method of election be used if it impairs the ability of a protected class to elect candidates of their choice and outlines violations, actions, and court remedies. 
  • Creates and funds a Voter Outreach and Education Fund whose goal is to educate voters on their voting rights.
  • Outlines an Attorney General's actions when there is reasonable cause to believe there has been a violation of the Election Code affecting rights of voters.
  • Establishes rules for voter assistance in the case of a non-English speaking voter who arrives at the polls without an interpreter.
  • Outlines actions for voters who are intimidated, threatened, or coerced by another person for all elections, selection of nominees, and all voting methods.
  • Outlines penalties and actions for intimidating an election officer.
  • Outlines penalties and actions for communicating false information to a registered voter to impede the voter in exercising his or her right to vote.
  • Outlines penalties and actions for officials committing illegal actions related to voting and carrying out official voting duties.   
  • Outlines penalties and actions for anyone furnishing a ballot to a non-English speaker and misinforming him or her about the content, or making changes to a ballot.

name: ELECTION CD-DIGITAL SIGNATURES
most_recent_action: Added Co-Sponsor Rep. La Shawn K. Ford
summary:
• Excludes nominating, candidate, and referendum petitions from digital signature options.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to adopt rules for collecting digital voter signatures for nominating, candidate, and referendum petitions by January 1, 2024.
  • Specifies rules for electronic devices being used for signature collection.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL BALLOTS
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a reporting system for election authorities to record returned mail in ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to record the number of mail in ballots received before and after election day, and on election day, and ballots received postmarked after election day.

name: ST BD EDUC-ELECT MEMBERS
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Dan McConchie
summary:
• Requires five members of the State Board of Education be elected in a nonpartisan election at the general election in 2024 and every four years after.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to hear and pass upon objections to nominations of candidates for State Board of Education.
  • Requires election authorities to open the returns and make abstracts of the votes for State Board of Education.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to proceed with a canvass after the election for elected members of the State Board of Election.
  • Provides that the State Board of Education should consist of five elected and eight appointed members.
  • Requires one election member from the State Board of Education come from each judicial district for a four year term.  
  • Outlines the petition for nomination process for State Board of Education candidates.
  • Provides vacancy procedures for appointed and elected members.
  • Outlines qualification requirements for candidates for State Board of Education.
  • Defines what constitutes quorum for the Board and what is needed for a vote to pass.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELEC CD-REPORTING TO ISBE
summary: • Requires the election authority to include methods of voting used in unit-by-unit vote totals to the State Board of Elections.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Outlines requirements for the appointment panels of judges to compare signatures on vote by mail ballots.
  • Outlines requirements for comparing signatures.
  • Outlines reasons for rejecting a ballot and procedures in the case of a rejection, including in some cases permitting a voter to cast a new ballot.

name: ELEC CD-DECEASED VOTERS
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a form to be used by election authorities to remove a voter from the roll.
  • Requires the county clerk to issue certifications of death records and use them to cancel registrations.

name: ELEC CD-CHANGE OF ADDRESS
summary: • Requires the county clerk to cross check each voter registration roll with the national Change of Address System and update voter information, including removing from the roll information from those who have self removed.

name: ELEC CD-REGISTRATION
most_recent_action: Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Eva Dina Delgado
summary:
• Allows certain forms at the department of motor vehicles to also be used as voter registration applications, provided the applicant presents identification confirming US citizenship and age, unless the applicant denies the option.
  • Provides that if an applicant to the department of motor vehicles does not submit identification confirming US citizenship and does not indicate the applicant is currently registered to vote in the state, then the application will not be a dual-purpose application.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to enter into an agreement with certain agencies for the purpose of updating an applicant's existing voter registration record.
  • Allows the agencies to transmit information about clients who may be registered to vote for the sole purpose of updating their registration.
  • Requires the Department of Healthcare and Family Services to implement automatic voter registration for Medicaid applicants by July 1, 2023.
  • Establishes rules for automatic voter registration applications sent without signature.
  • Establishes procedures for automatic voter registration applications received for individuals protected by certain programs designed for confidentiality of victims.
  • Outlines certain notification requirements for individuals who are automatically registered to vote.
  • Makes other conforming changes to election code.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to use a Voter Identification Card to each registered voter who does not have an acceptable form of photo ID, and includes information required on the card, valid dates, and uses.
  • Clarifies that the General Assembly intends to advise the Secretary of State on how to issue the identification card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for Voter Identification Cards and provide Cards to any registered voter who qualifies.
  • Lists documents requires for a Voter Identification Card.
  • Provides for exemptions for certain voters.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification to be able to vote, including the Voter Identification Card.
  • Includes the Voter Identification Card in other related election ID rules.
  • Allows a provisional voter 10 days to provide the proper authority with required photo ID.

name: ELEC CD-PRE-REGISTRATION
most_recent_action: Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Aaron M. Ortiz
summary:
• Replaces the "State Board of Elections website" with "electronic voter registration portal" in existing legislation.
  • Allows qualified residents to preregister to vote on or after their 16th birthday using the online voter registration system.
  • Outlines related requirements for election authorities in processing the applications.
  • Allows qualified 17-year-olds, who will be 18 by the date of the next election, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.
  • Deems qualified 16-year-olds competent to execute and attest any voter registration forms.

name: ELECTION CD-JUDGE'S INITIAL
summary: • Removes the requirement that judges initial ballots of those who ordered a vote by mail ballot, but came to the polls in person.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to use a Voter Identification Card to each registered voter who does not have an acceptable form of photo ID, and includes information required on the card, valid dates, and uses.
  • The General Assembly intends to advise the Secretary of State on how to issue the identification card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for Voter Identification Cards and provide Cards to any registered voter who qualifies.
  • Lists documents requires for a Voter Identification Card.
  • Provides for exemptions for certain voters.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification to be able to vote, including the Voter Identification Card.
  • Includes the Voter Identification Card in other related election ID rules.
  • Allows a provisional voter 10 days to provide the proper authority with required photo ID.

name: ELECTION CD-OBJECTION NOTICE
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum)
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections within 24 hours of receiving a certificate of nomination, nominations papers, or proposed question, and the objector's petition, to send a call by registered or certified mail to the election authority to whom the ballot is certified, along with others who were previously listed.
  • Establishes that the chair of the election board other than the State Board of Elections will be responsible for having the sheriff serve a copy of the call to each of the designated officers or other individuals.

name: ELECT CODE-ELECTION JUDGES
summary: • Allows election authorities to reduce the number of judges in each precinct from five to three.

name: ELECTIONS-VOTE BY MAIL NOTICE
summary: • Excludes permanent vote by mail voters from the requirement that a notice of a vote by mail option be sent before an election.

name: ELECTION CD-PUBLIC QUESTIONS
summary:
• Adds "proposed statewide advisory public questions" to the list of types of hearings the State Electoral Board may conduct in the case of objections to a petition.  
  • Removes provisions specifying requirements for statewide advisory public questions, including petitions and referenda.
  • Removes certain responsibilities from election authorities, including petition signature verification. 
  • Removes certain filing requirements for those submitting a statewide advisory public question.
  • Modifies procedures for valid signature calculation and petition verification watchers.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTER SIGNATURE
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for low-income voters
summary:
• Requires that if judges find a signature on a certificate does not match a signature on a registration card, the voter must provide a valid, approved state identification.
  • Allows that judges may find that signatures do not match if one is in cursive and the other is printed.

name: ELEC CD-SOCIALIST ORGS
summary: • Changes the oath for candidates filing for election to include swearing that they are not affiliated with "any socialist organization."

name: ELECTION CD-ELECTION PRECINCTS
summary:
• Allows County Board with a population over 3 million to divide, adjust, or consolidate election precincts.
  • If it is not practicable for the County Board to change the boundaries of the precincts after the decennial census, they may do so at their next regular June or July meeting.
  • Adds consolidating to the list of options for a County Board in adjusting precincts.
  • If a County Board fails to adjust precincts in the year following the decennial census, then existing districts will continue until the next regular June meeting.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER REGISTRATION
summary:
• Requires election authorities to automatically register any voter within 90 days of receipt of information from the National Change of Address database.
  • Requires the county clerk to send notice to appear for a hearing to a juror who the clerk believes is not a qualified voter, and outlines relevant provisions.
  • Requires the county clerk to conduct a verification of voter registrations on a specified timetable.
  • Requires the clerk of the circuit court to notify jury officials of each jury summons returned due to a change of address, and the jury administrator to send local election authorities a list of all such address changes every three months.

name: ELECTION CD-VOTE CENTERS
summary: • Expands the requirement that an election authority identify health and safety requirements for a voting location to all elections.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Provides that the General Assembly intends to provide the Secretary of State guidance on how to issue the Voter Identification Card to those without acceptable form of photo ID.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and establish procedures for identity verification.
  • Lists acceptable forms of ID for voting.
  • Provides religious exemptions and exemptions for indigent individuals.
  • Outlines ID requirements for voters registered by mail.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.
  • Aligns other provisions with the new Voter Identification Card rules.

name: ELECTION CODE-BALLOT FORMAT
summary: • Requires all ballots used in elections to contain an "Illinois State Board of Elections" watermark and to be numbered, prohibiting linkage of the ballot number to a specific voter.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTER REGISTRATION
summary:
• Requires the Illinois State Police and the State Board of Elections to create an automatic voter registration program for those completing applications related to a Firearm Owners Identification card or a Concealed Carry Permit.
  • Allows the above applications to also serve as a residential address update for voter registration purposes.
  • Requires that the applicant be given an opportunity to decline to register.
  • Requires an attestation by signature that the applicant meets the qualifications to register.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the Illinois State Police related to applications, notifications, information transmission, and qualifications.
  • Provides that a Firearm Owners Identification Card application or concealed carry license application constitute an application to register to vote in Illinois.
  • Defines "dual purpose application."
  • Makes other complying changes.

name: ELECTION-INCAPACITATED ELECTOR
summary: • Allows eligible incapacitated voters to vote by mail or onsite, rather than onsite only.

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
summary:
• Requires appropriate officials to transmit a death certificate to the county clerk within seven days of the death.
  • Requires the county clerk and coroner to report quarterly to certify full compliance.
  • Allows for any person to request a copy of the report and outlines penalties for not providing the report, including the role of a circuit court judge in compliance and penalties.

name: ELEC CD-CANCEL REGISTRATION
summary:
• Requires that no voter registration be canceled without following the procedures of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993.
  • Provides for cancelation of a voter registration if a voter becomes inactive by not voting in two consecutive general federal elections, provided National Voter Registration Act procedures are followed, unless the voter acts to restore their name to active voter status.
  • Provides for the cancelation of a voter registration if the voter requests this in writing.
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if the election authority receives notice that the voter is incarcerated in a US, state, or county correctional facility, if the incarceration is the result of a criminal conviction or judgment of conviction.
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if a person has a judgment of conviction for a crime and it is found at the time that the voter lacks the required qualifications to be a registered voter.
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if a certified copy of a final judgment order or a final determination of an administrative tribunal finds that the voter lacks the required qualifications to be a voter. 
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if election authorities receive a voter's death certificate or equivalent.
  • Requires the county clerk to issue a death certificate and requires the clerk to cancel the deceased person's voter registration.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT SECURITY
summary:
• Establishes that recordings of collection sites for vote by mail ballots are public records subject to related laws.
  • Requires collection sites to be established only on public grounds where normal local government business is conducted and where there is no residential component.
  • Requires all collection sites be recorded by security cameras.
  • Requires authorities to retain recordings for 90 days after each election and make recordings available for inspection and copying under FOIA.

name: ELECTION BALLOT RANDOMIZATION
summary:
• Requires names of candidates on a ballot to appear in random order, requiring each election district or precinct to choose a different order, as much as mathematically possible.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to follow the randomization requirements for certifying the election.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to choose a software vendor who can conduct the described randomization of names.
  • Requires any software purchased to be used solely for this purpose.

name: ELECTION CODE-EARLY VOTING
summary: • Amends the early voting period to end on the Friday immediately before the election, and requires the early voting polling place to stay open until then.

name: ELECTIONS-VARIOUS
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to establish a system for publishing and certifying election results.
  • Requires the county clerk to quarterly confirm that deceased voters and those who moved away are no longer registered to vote in the county.
  • Requires the board of election commissioners to confirm that deceased voters and those who moved away are no longer registered to vote in the municipality.
  • Requires the county clerk to update vote totals at least every 24 hours after Election Day and includes required information.

name: COUNTY EXECUTIVE FORM-BOARD
summary:
• Requires the chief elected county board member, when learning of a vacancy in an elective county office, to declare a vacancy exists and notify appropriate officials within three days of the vacancy.
  • Requires the vacancy be filled within 60 days by appointment by the chief elected county board member, with advice and consent of the county board.
  • Defines "county executive form of government" to allow elected members to choose a chief administrative official, speaker, or board chair.

name: ELECT-MUNI ELECT COMM
summary: • Allows the county board or county commissioners in a county with a population less than 100,000 to dissolve a municipal board of election commissioners, by ordinance or resolution, and transfer its functions to the county clerk.

name: GENERAL ELECTION DAY
summary:
• Establishes the date of the general election is the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November in even years.
  • Makes conforming changes to election code.
  • Establishes that colleges, universities, agencies, and community college offices will be closed on general election day.

name: CITIZENS EMPOWERMENT ACT
summary:
• Creates the Citizen Empowerment Act.
  • Provides for the dissolution of a unit of local government by voters.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Outlines the steps for a petition for a referendum to dissolve a local government unit, including ballot placement.
  • Outlines voting requirements for the referendum.
  • Provides for the transfer of rights and duties with the dissolution of a unit of local government.
  • Includes the Citizen Empowerment Act in other electoral code.

name: ELECT CODE-ELECTION JUDGES
summary:
• Allows an election authority to reduce the number of judges of an election in each precinct from five to three for any election.
  • Makes conforming changes to the election code.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT PRINTING
summary: • Requires lettering on ballots to be in both capital and lowercase letters, conforming with standard English guidelines.

name: ELECT CODE-CANDIDATE OATH
summary: • Requires a candidate to swear they are unaffiliated with hate groups and white supremacist organizations in the candidate oath.

name: ELEC CD-PRE-REGISTRATION
summary:
• Changes "State Board of Elections website" to "electronic voter registration portal."
  • Allows qualified voters to preregister to vote after their 16th birthday with certain procedures.
  • Requires preregistration to take place using the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows 17-year-olds who will be 18 at the time of the next election to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public questions.
  • Establishes that 16-year-olds are deemed competent to execute and attest to any voter registration forms.

name: ELEC CD-MAIL BALLOT/DISABILITY
summary:
• Defines "electronic transmission" and "voter with a disability."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish a procedure to sent vote by mail ballots electronically to persons with disability so that they can privately mark their ballot using assistive technology.
  • Requires the election authority to transmit a vote by mail ballot for a voter with disability within three business days if the application arrives after the election authority begins transmitting ballots.
  • Requires ballots received and marked to be printed by the voter and returned to the election authority.
  • Allows election authorities to deliver an official ballot electronically in certain instances.
  • Requires an election authority to provide printed slips, or electronic versions for vote by mail, with full instructions for marking the ballot.
  • Requires election authorities to provide voters with electronically transmitted ballots to provide the same instructions, certifications, and balloting materials as for other voters, to the extent possible.

name: ELECTIONS-VOTE BY MAIL NOTICE
summary: • Requires election authorities to notify voters of the option for permanent vote by mail status, unless a voter has already applied for permanent vote by mail status, or a voter has submitted a written request to be excluded from permanent vote by mail status.

name: ELECTION CD-ELECTION PRECINCTS
summary:
• Requires the County Board in counties with a population over three million to divide, adjust, or consolidate precincts in June each year.
  • Allows the County Board to divide, adjust, or consolidate boundaries of precincts after the decennial census within certain timetables.

name: ELECTIONS-PAPER BALLOTS ONLY
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,Chain of custody,Cybersecurity
summary:
• Defines "hand-marked paper ballot."
  • Requires election authorities to allow voters to use hand-marked paper ballots, including allowing voters to inspect and verify their vote before casting the ballot.
  • Requires hand marked paper ballots to be counted by hand or read by optical scan technology or another counting method.
  • Requires election judges to advise voters of the opportunity to correct any error on the ballot.
  • Requires ballots be preserved in a way that keeps them anonymous.
  • Establishes hand marked paper ballots as the official ballot, to be preserved and suitable to be used for recount or audit.
  • Requires hand marked paper ballots be the true and correct record of the cast vote if there are inconsistencies with electronic tallies.
  • Provides that if hand marked paper ballots are compromised in sufficient number to change the result of the election, the appropriate remedy should be made in accordance with Electoral Code, and the electronic tally should not be used as the only basis for determining the result.
  • Establishes security measures for voter registration rolls, ballots, ballot boxes, poll lists, poll books, and voting tabulators.
  • Prohibits remote access to electronic devices used in certain voting procedures.

name: ELECTION CD-VOTE CENTERS
summary: • Provides that election authorities establish a voting center where all voters in the jurisdiction can vote for all elections.

name: ELECTION CD-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to adopt rules to provide a certified remote accessible vote by mail for voters with disabilities where voters may mark their ballot using assistive technology.
  • Requires election authorities to transmit a vote by mail ballot to a disabled voter within two business days after vote by mail ballots begin being transmitted.
  • Requires voters to print and return ballots received in vote by mail for voters with disabilities.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to adopt rules, including certification standards, for remote accessible vote by mail and a method for voters with disability to request a vote by mail ballot.
  • Defines related terms.
  • Codifies the affirmation for the application for vote by mail ballot for people with disabilities.
  • Requires election authorities to provide applicants for electronic transmission of ballots with the same instructions, certifications, and balloting materials as others sending ballots by mail, to the greatest extent possible.
  • Requires that a duplicate ballot not include the invalid votes appearing on the original ballot.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes non-substantive changes to the election code.

name: GENERAL ELECTION DAY
summary:
• Establishes general election day as a state holiday. 
  • Makes conforming changes to the election code.
  • Requires college, university, agency, and community college offices to be closed on general election day.

name: ELECTION CD-OBJECTION NOTICE
summary:
• Requires the chair of the electoral board, within 24 hours of receipt of an objector's petition, to notify the election authority to whom the ballot is certified, in addition to previously listed offices.
  • Requires the chair of the electoral board (other than the State Board of Elections) to cause the sheriff to serve a copy of the call to each designated officer or person.

name: ELECTION-INCAPACITATED ELECTOR
summary: • Allows for physically incapacitated voters to either vote on the premisis, or to vote by mail.

name: ELEC CD-RANKED CHOICE VOTING
most_recent_action: Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments
summary:
• Provides that ranked choice voting be used for candidates for General Assembly, Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, Secretary of State, Comptroller, and Treasurer during regular and special elections.
  • Outlines ballot content rules for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines rules for voting a ranked choice ballot.
  • Outlines tallying procedures and rules for ranked choice voting.

name: ELECT CODE-DEEP FAKE VIDEO
summary:
• Defines deep fake videos.
  • Provides that a person is committing a Class A misdemeanor if the person creates, publishes, and distributes a deep fake video with the intent to injure a candidate or influence the results of an election within 30 days of the election.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Adds the Voter Identification Card as an acceptable form of photo ID for voting.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and the Secretary of State to adopt procedures for identity verification of registered voters.
  • Provides certain exemptions.
  • Lists acceptable forms of ID for voting.
  • Makes changes to align the election code.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Non-substantive change to the Election Code.

name: ELEC CD-EQUIPMENT/AUDITS
summary:
• Requires each early voting polling place to have sufficient paper ballots for voters who request them.
  • Requires a 10% election day audit of all votes cast for each statewide, countywide, federal, municipal, or other race or proposition on election day, where there is more than 50,000 registered eligible voters.
  • Requires audits to take place as soon as possible after the close of polls at the location where votes are counted, but not interfere with the reporting of election results.
  • Requires the audit be conducted by election judges with staffing requirements laid out in the legislation.
  • Provides for a method for the random selection of ballots and for recording the results of the random selection.
  • Provides a system for examining and recording ballots for the audit.
  • Requires election authorities to create and print an audit summary form before election day listing the races and propositions to be audited, with spaces for recording the results of the audit, and certain other requirements.
  • Outlines requirements for completion of the audit summary form and distribution and publicity of copies of the form. 
  • Requires election authorities to collect all precinct audit reports and create a consolidated report to be published within 24 hours of the polls closing, and requires authorities to certify the election day audit results.
  • Outlines storage and public availability requirements for the audit.
  • Provides that the reports are admissible as evidence as required.
  • Requires a parallel, independent audit be conducted for each race or proposition in each election.
  • Outlines staffing, timeline, and committee composition rules for the audit.
  • Outlines rules for the parallel election tabulation and audit, including request for proposals, timeline, awarding the contracting, funding, contractor qualifications, licensing and bonding requirements, and requires the contractor have access to all records of the election.
  • Outlines requirements for the report submitted by the contractor in the parallel audit including timeline, procedures, certification or non-certification criteria, what should be examined, questions to be answered, and information required. 
  • Clarifies that the parallel election tabulation and audit reports are public property, in the public domain, available under FOIA, and may be posted on a website.
  • Requires the parallel election tabulation and audit reports be admissible as evidence as required.
  • Creates the Illinois Election Integrity Fund as a special fund in the State treasury and clarifies funding mechanisms.
  • Defines "approved independent testing authority."
  • Requires precinct tabulation optical scan technology voting systems to fulfill voluntary provisions and mandatory requirements from proper authorities and to fulfill testing requirements by approved testing authorities.

name: ELEC CD-AUDIT OF BALLOTS
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to develop procedures for conducting audits of affidavit signatures from regular elections, beginning in the general election of 2022.
  • Requires each election authority to randomly select 1% of ballots cast to be audited in accordance with the procedure developed by the State Board of Elections.

name: ELECTION CODE-VARIOUS
summary:
• Revises information requirements for voter registration record cards.
  • Establishes reasonable costs for voter registration records and data.
  • Prohibits placing voter registration records on the internet with unrestricted access.
  • Lists confidential information from voter registration records.
  • Provides that a government entity or employee or officer will not be held civilly liable for disclosure of information unless it is due to "gross negligence or willfulness."
  • Outlines guidelines for providing voter registration records for election, scholarly, or journalistic purposes.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT TRACKING
summary:
• Defines "change in status," "voter registration database," and "trackable ballot."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a system to track ballots, including updates of changes.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to update a voter electronically about any changes.
  • Provides language for consenting to receive notifications.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to update a voter's information in the statewide voter registration database.

name: ELECTION CODE-VOTER ROLLS
summary:
• Requires a county clerk to use death records to cancel a voter registration.
  • Requires certified death records be sent to the county clerk within seven days of death.
  • Requires the county clerk or coroner to report quarterly to the county board and certify its full compliance.
  • Requires the county clerk to monthly request records of permanent address changes from the Postal Service and update voter records.
  • Establishes that any person can request a copy of the required reports and establishes penalties for failing to provide them, including circuit court jurisdiction, actions, and penalties.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a policy concerning chain of custody and secure storage of vote by mail ballots.
  • Requires the policy include: procedures to destroy certain ballots, reporting requirements, and creation of a public database.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes a non-substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes a non substantive change to the election code.

summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to election code.
