summary: • This bill makes a non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill includes a non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes non-substantive change to election code.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and establish procedures for identity verification.
  • Offers practices for those seeking a religious exemption for the photo ID.
  • Lists acceptable forms of ID for voting.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.
  • Aligns other provisions with the new Voter Identification Card rules.

name: ELECTION CODE-VOTER ROLLS
summary:
• Requires the county clerk to cancel the voter registration of anyone who died in the preceding month.
  • Requires certain qualified individuals to transfer notification of death within seven days to the county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to monthly request change of address records from the US Postal Service and update affected voter registrations.
  • Outlines reporting requirements for the county clerk.
  • Outlines penalties for not fulfilling reporting requirements.
  • Outlines powers of a circuit court judge in reporting, including ordering certain information to be produced, assessing penalties, and coverage of costs.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT AUDIT
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to develop procedures for conducting audits of signatures on ballot applications in regular elections starting with the general election in 2022.
  • Requires each election authroity to randomly select 1% of applications and audit in accordance with the developed procedure.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT TRACKING
summary:
• Defines "change of status."
  • Defines "trackable ballot."
  • Defines "voter registration database."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a state or locally based system to track the status of a trackable ballot by July 1, 2022.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to send a voter who has elected to track his or her ballot electronic notifications.
  • Requires notification be given in the ballot tracking application that the voter will receive electronic notifications, and requires that the voter specifically consent to this.
  • Requires the election authoruty to transmit voter information to the State Board of Elections.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a policy concerning the chain of custody and secure storage of vote by mail ballots, including procedures to destroy a ballot when a voter votes in person after voting by mail, reporting requirements, database creation and publication of data.
  • Requires the policy to be implemented by each election authority.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Requires a resident from a voter's residential address to endorse a voters vote by mail envelope to verify a voter's identity and residency. 
  • If this is not possible, a resident of the voter's precinct may endorse the envelope, or the voter may include a utility bill or lease with the ballot to verify their identity.

name: ELEC CODE-RESULT ANNOUNCEMENT
summary: • Requires 100% of ballots to be counted before the results of the election are announced.

name: ELEC CODE-BALLOT COUNTING
summary: • Requires that after four hours of counting ballots, local election authorities determine how many ballots are left to be counted for each precinct, and what type of ballots are left to count.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Requires a voter to apply for a vote by mail ballot 60-90 days before an election, rather than 5-90 days.
  • Make conforming changes.

name: ELEC CD-VOTING MACHINES
summary: • Prohibits any voting machine from being connected to the internet while being used to cast votes.

name: ELEC CODE-BALLOT POSTMARK
summary:
• Requires a vote by mail ballot to be postmarked no later than three days before election day to be counted, rather than election day.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: ELEC CD-AUDIT OF BALLOTS
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to develop procedures for conducting audits of affidavit signatures on ballots cast in regular elections by the general election in 2022.
  • Requires each election authority to select a random 1% of ballots cast to be audited.

name: ELECTION CODE-VOTER ROLLS
summary:
• Requires the county clerk to cancel the voter registration of anyone who died in the preceding month.
  • Requires certain qualified individuals to transfer notification of death within seven days to the county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to monthly request change of address records from the US Postal Service and update affected voter registrations.
  • Outlines reporting requirements for the county clerk.
  • Outlines penalties for the clerk not fulfilling reporting requirements.
  • Outlines powers of a circuit court judge in reporting, including ordering certain information to be produced, assessing penalties, and coverage of costs.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT TRACKING
summary:
• Defines "change of status."
  • Defines "trackable ballot."
  • Defines "voter registration database."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a state or locally based system to track the status of a trackable ballot by July 1, 2022.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to send a voter who has elected to track his or her ballot electronic notifications.
  • Requires notification be given in the ballot tracking application that the voter will receive electronic notifications, and that the voter's provided information will be included in the statewide voter registration database.

name: ELEC CD-ELEC PRECINCT NUMBERS
summary:
• Outlines meeting requirements for dividing election precincts for County Boards in counties with under three million inhabitants, where the number of votes cast in a precinct on election day in the most recent general election was more than 1,200.
  • Changes "district" to "precinct" throughout the text.
  • Allows precincts to be consolidated when dividing them.
  • Make conforming changes to election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
most_recent_action: Senate Floor Amendment No. 1 Pursuant to Senate Rule 3-9(b) / Referred to Assignments
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: ELEC CODE-INCARCERATED BAN
most_recent_action: Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Mark L. Walker
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: • Repeals provisions prohibiting a person from voting who is serving a prison sentence until he or she is released from prison.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes a non-substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTED CHICAGO SCHOOL BOARD
summary:
• Changes the name of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.
  • Requires Chicago Board of Education members be elected to five year terms in 2022, with successors being elected to four-year terms.
  • Requires 2022 Chicago Board of Education elections to be nonpartisan.
  • Establishes that each Chicago Board of Education member will be elected at each consolidated election beginning in April 2027 to succeed the incumbent member whose term ends.
  • Requires the city of Chicago to be subdivided by the General Assembly into 20 electoral districts for school board.
  • Requires one representative from each district, plus one at-large representative.
  • Outlines requirements for meetings, organization, and vacancy on the school board.
  • Outlines prohibitions for school board members and conflicts of interest, including penalties.
  • Outlines candidacy and nomination requirements for school board elections.
  • Removes certain health insurance, benefit, and compensation provisions.
  • Specifies language for nomination petitions for school board.
  • Provides that the Inspector General be appointed by the board instead of the mayor starting March 22, 2022 and the board appoint vacancies starting March 24, 2026.
  • Requires the General Assembly to redistrict school board districts after each decennial census with certain requirements.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Brian W. Stewart
summary: • Makes non substantive change to election code.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTION HOLIDAYS
most_recent_action: Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Jacqueline Y. Collins
summary: • Amends "State holiday" to include general election day, general primary day, consolidated election day, and consolidated primary day and makes complying changes in procurement, school, and university code.

name: ELEC CD-CANCEL REGISTRATION
summary:
• Implements the National Voter Registration Act and order of the Circuit Court regarding canceling voter registrations.
  • Requires procedures to cancel voter registrations from the National Voter Registration Act be followed, including providing notice.
  • Provides that a voter who has not voted in two consecutive federal general elections is inactive and will be canceled, if the voter has taken no actions specified in the Act to restore his or her name.
  • Requires an election authority to cancel the voter registration of a voter who requests it in writing.
  • Lists reasons a voter's registration may be canceled.
  • Requires the county clerk to cancel the registration of a deceased voter, following certain guidelines.

name: GOVT ETHICS-ECONOMIC INTERESTS
most_recent_action: Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Laura M. Murphy
summary:
• Defines "asset," "creditor," "debt," "diversified funds," "economic relationship," "family," "filer," "income," "investment real estate," "lobbying," "lobbyist," "personal residence," "sector funds," "spouse," "affected office," and "candidate political committee." 
  • Prohibits legislators from engaging in promoting or opposing the passage of any legislative matter affecting the interests of any individual, association, or corporation, in distinction from the interests of the people of the state as a whole.
  • Prohibits legislators from engaging in compensated lobbying of any government body on behalf of any lobbying entity registered in the state of Illinois or any Illinois county, municipality, or township.
  • Prohibits any appointed person from serving as an officer or becoming a candidate of a candidate political committee.
  • Requires that an appointed person within 30 days of their appointment implement certain measures related to their affiliation with a candidate political committee.
  • Requires the General Assembly to be in compliance with this legislation within 30 days of its effective date.
  • Requires that the interest of a spouse or any other party is considered the same as the interest of the person making the statement of economic interest.
  • Provides that campaign receipts are not to be included in the statement of economic interests.
  • Lists the interests that are required to file, including certain assets, income, debt, employers within the government, lobbying.
  • Provides that every five years the Secretary of State will adjust disclosure amounts based on inflation.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to develop guidance for filing the statement of economic interests and make it available on their website.
  • Removes conflicting guidance.
  • Provides the instructions for the statement of economic interests and provides that it may be filed with a county clerk, in addition to the Secretary of State.
  • Allows that a filers statement should be made with reasonable, good faith guidance from the Secretary of State and should not constitute a willful false or incomplete statement for classification of misdemeanor offenses.
  • Adds Supreme Court Justices, appellate court judges, circuit court judges, and judicial retention to the list of those who should not use the internet to file their statement.
  • Clarifies that candidates, officials, and officers may not hold a virtual fundraising event in Sangamon County on certain days related to when the legislature is in session if the person is not in Sangamon County.
  • Prohibits a former officer of the executive or legislative branch from engaging in activities that require registration under the Lobbyist Registration Act for a period of six months after leaving office.
  • Adds fiscal administration of state contracts as a reason to work with certain state agencies or entities on issues dealing with procurement and the prohibition of a revolving door.
  • Requires the Legislative Inspector General to be a full time employee of the state, outlines compensation requirements, and requires him or her to post office hours in Springfield.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits a limited activity committee from accepting contributions, except in specific circumstances and under certain guidelines.
  • Provides that a limited activity committee may only make certain expenditures.
  • Requires that starting January 1, 2022 compensation paid to members of the General Assembly be paid bi-monthly and prorates payment to members who resign and those completing a vacancy term.
  • Provides that state regulations regarding lobbying supercede local rules.

name: ELECT CODE-GA VACANCIES
most_recent_action: Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Eva Dina Delgado
summary:
• Requires that an appointing committee to fill a vacancy in the General assembly convene within three days and establishes guidelines for their work.
  • Prohibits the a State Senator or Representative, who is also a committee member, from appointing his or her successor and establishes related voting rules.

name: ELECT-MUNI ELECT COMM
summary: • Allows a county board or board of county commissioners in a county with a population of less than 100,000 to dissolve a municipal board of election commissioners and transfer functions to the county clerk.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTING AVAILABILITY
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Doris Turner
summary:
• Requires a permanent polling place for early voting to remain open starting 22 days before the during regular hours.
  • Requires a permanent polling place for early voting to remain open starting 11 days before the election 8:30am-7pm or 9am-7:30pm every day.
  • Requires early voting locations to remain open at least 16 hours in the final weekend before the election.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
ELEC CD-ELEC PRECINCT NUMBERS
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Jason Plummer
summary:
• Outlines meeting requirements for dividing election precincts for County Boards in counties with under three million inhabitants, where the number of votes cast in a precinct on election day in the most recent general election was more than 1,200.
  • Changes "district" to "precinct" throughout the text.
  • Allows precincts to be consolidated when dividing them.
  • Make conforming changes to election code.

name: FOIA/ELECTIONS-CYBERSECURITY
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Neil Anderson
summary:
• Includes election related security measures as exempt from FOIA requests in all relevant agencies.
  • Removes a paragraph about public hearings related to cyber-security efforts.
  • Changes "Help America Vote Act" to "2018 Help America Vote Act Election Security Grant" in related legislation.

name: ELEC CD-OVERSEAS CITIZEN
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Dale Fowler
summary: • Allows a US citizen who has never lived in the US, but whose parent or legal guardian is a qualified voter, eligibility to register and vote in federal elections where his or her parent or guardian lives.

name: ELEC CODE-ELECTION DAY-SCHOOLS
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Time off for voting
summary:
• Requires schools to be closed on election day regardless of whether the school is used as a polling site.
  • Requires school districts to close all schools on the day of a general election.

name: ELECTION CODE-DISABILITIES
categories: Voter participation deadlines,In-person voter assistance,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary:
• Changes the definition of "person with disability" to include intellectual or developmental disabilities.
  • Requires election authorities to give 75 days notice, rather than 60, before each election about the availability of voting and registration aids through the Federal Voting and Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act.
  • Requires aids be for voting in person, early in person, or by mail. 
  • Outlines responsibilities of the county clerk for mailing and receiving vote by mail ballots 14-20 days before an election for a person with a disability.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections and Department of Human Services to create a system where vote by mail voters may return their ballots through other means.
  • Adapts code to conform to the new standard.

name: ELEC CD-PERMANENT VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Allows voters to apply to be added to a list of permanent vote by mail voters.
  • Requires permanent vote by mail voters to stay on the vote by mail list until they change their registration, request to be removed, or if the election authority receives notice that they are registered in another county.
  • Requires election authorities to notify qualified voters about the option of being placed on the permanent vote by mail list 45-90 days before an election, with certain requirements.
  • Provides language for the application for a permanent vote by mail application.
  • Requires election authorities to allow permanent vote by mail voters to change their party affiliation for a primary election.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER REGISTRATION AGE
summary:
• Changes "State Board of Elections website" to "electronic voter registration portal."
  • Allows qualified 16 year olds to preregister to vote using the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows a 17 year old, who will be 18 at the next election, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.
  • Deems a 16 year old competent to execute and attest to any voter registration forms.

name: ELEC CD-GA APPT TRANSPARENCY
summary:
• Requires that when a vacancy occurs for State Senator or Representative, the appropriate legislative committee to fill the vacancy must notify the public of the vacancy and the replacement process, including providing information of where interested members of the public may apply for an appointment. 
  • Requires the legislative committee to provide the public notice of an impending vote to fill the vacancy at least six days before the vote.
  • Requires a meeting to fill a vacancy in the General Assembly be open to the public, subject to the Open Meetings Act, be recorded, and be broadcast for the public. 
  • Requires the Governor comply with the above requirements, to the extent possible, if he or she fills a vacancy for State Senate or House.

name: ELEC CD-RISK-LIMITING AUDIT
summary:
• Defines "audit unit."
  • Lists conditions to be satisfied for a precinct, set of ballots, or single ballot to be an audit unit.
  • Requires each election authority to conduct an audit following an election, notifying the State Board of Elections before election day about the type of audit to be conducted.
  • Requires election authorities to also conduct a random audit of 5% of ballots cast by mail.
  • Outlines steps and requirements for a random audit.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to consult certain experts to adopt rules and criteria for the conduct of a risk-limiting audit, and outlines steps and requirements.
  • Requires written notice to state central committee chairs when either audit is conducted.
  • Removes certain test requirements for vote counting equipment and outlines steps for if an error is detected following an audit.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
summary:
• Requires that one elector for US President and Vice President come from each congressional district.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee of a party to choose two electors at-large.
  • Makes complying changes to Election Code.
  • Requires each congressional district elector to cast his or her ballot for the candidate who received the highest number of votes in the congressional district.
  • Requires each at-large elector to cast his or her ballot for the candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state.

name: ELEC CD-PRE-REGISTRATION
summary:
• Requires online voter registration applicants to use the "electronic voter registration portal" instead of the State Board of Elections website.
  • Allows individuals to preregister to vote starting on their 16th birthday, requiring the registration to be held by election authorities until the individual reaches voting age.
  • Requires those preregistering to vote to use the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows 17 year olds who will be 18 by the time of the next election, and are otherwise eligible to vote, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.

name: ELEC CD-PRESIDENTIAL ELECTORS
summary:
• Requires one presidential elector be designated from each congressional district in the state.
  • Makes related changes to ballot requirements.
  • Establishes that the presidential elector with the highest number of votes in a district, or at-large, must cast the electoral vote for the presidential and Vice President candidates of his or her political party.

name: ELEC CD-CAMPAIGN MATERIALS
summary:
• Defines "actual malice" and "campaign material."
  • Prohibits anyone or any organization from distributing campaign materials containing superimposed images of candidates with actual malice, unless the picture is labeled "this picture is not an accurate representation of fact."
  • Outlines options for restraining orders, civil actions, fines, and other court actions related to campaign materials alleged to be inaccurate or published with actual malice.
  • Provides for certain exemptions.
  • Defines "materially deceptive audio or visual media" and lists conditions in which it may be used.
  • Prohibits anyone from distributing with actual malice, materially deceptive audio and visual media of a candidate with the intent to injure the person's reputation or deceive, within 60 days of the election. 
  • Provides exceptions.
  • Outlines requirements for disclosures for visual and audio media.
  • Provides pathways for relief for candidates whose voices or likeness is used in visual and audio media.
  • Provides exceptions.
  • Provides that the provisions in this section are severable.
  • Provides that proceedings related to registration of voters, certification of candidates, and certification of ballot measures will be heard in order of their date of filing and will be given precedence.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL TRACKER
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections, in conjunction with election authorities, by January 1, 2023 to implement a free, secure system to track vote-by-mail ballots, and to notify a voter if his or her vote by mail ballot was accepted in the counting, with reasons if it was rejected. 
  • Requires the election authority to make the system available for each election, with timelines.

name: COM COL-CHICAGO-ELECT BOARD
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Nonpartisan elections,Vacancy procedures
summary:
• Changes the name of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.
  • Requires in the 2022 primary that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and the Illinois Community College District 508 be elected in a non partisan election for a term of four years.
  • Requires that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and Illinois Community College District 508 be elected at each consolidated election starting in April 2023 to succeed incumbent members whose term ends after the consolidated election.
  • Outlines board appointments, elections, membership, and vacancy procedures for community college districts.
  • Establishes language for nomination petitions, as well as instructions for content, processing, and timelines, in the City of Chicago.
  • Outlines rules for ballots and petitions related to community college district elections.
  • Requires the City of Chicago to create 20 trustee districts by January 1, 2022 and requires they be reapportioned the year after the decennial census.

name: ELECT CODE-ELECTION JUDGES
summary:
• Allows an election authority to reduce the number of judges of an election in each precinct from five to three for any election.
  • Makes conforming changes to the election code.

name: ELEC CD-AUDIT FOR CAUSE
summary:
• Requires the treasurer of a political committee to preserve all records and accounts before January 1, 2022 for two years, and for seven years after that date.
  • Allows the board to require a political committee to conduct an audit of its financial records if: a candidate admits a violation of the law in testimony, a candidate is convicted of misuse of funds, the committee fails to comply with a board order regarding reporting, or if a statement or organization by a political committee included officers or candidates of a political committee that was administratively terminated in the last 24 months.
  • Establishes that the audit period is within the board's discretion, but may not exceed seven years.

name: ELEC CD-DISABILITY/BALLOTS
summary:
• Defines "electronic ballot marking tool."
  • Provides that the General Assembly intends that vote by mail be fully accessible to all voters. 
  • Provides that the State Board of Elections will work with election authorities and the disability community to develop procedures and technology to provide vote by mail ballots in alternative formats that meet the requirements of other vote by mail ballots and do not require assistance.
  • Requires adaptation of the electronic ballot marking tool, enabling voters to mark their ballot privately and independently.
  • Requires implementation of alternative methods for voters to return the ballot, including secure email portals, conforming with Illinois accessibility legislation and technology and security standards.
  • Requires each election authority to provide the option of a fully electronic ballot allowing voters with disability to vote a secret ballot without assistance starting January 1, 2023.

name: ELEC CODE-TRACK MAIL BALLOT
summary:
• Defines "trackable."
  • Requires mailed ballots to be trackable.
  • Requires election authorities to mail, or deliver in person, return envelopes that are postage prepaid and trackable with vote by mail ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to maintain a list of applicants who have requested, received, or returned vote by mail ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to provide online access to the vote by mail ballot list, with certain additional information and updating on their website.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Drop-box availability,In-person voter assistance,Drop-box security
summary:
• Allows the Board to distribute Help America Vote Act funds to election authorities for maintenance of secure collection sites for return of vote mail ballots.
  • Allows election authorities to establish curbside voting for early voting and election day.
  • Requires curbside voting programs to designate at least two election judges from opposite parties per vehicle with certain ballot security provisions.
  • Requires election officials to accept vote by mail ballots returned with insufficient postage.
  • Allows election authorities to maintain collection sites for postage free return of vote by mail ballots and outlines a process for collection, timelines, security, and authority.
  • Establishes the State Board of Elections will establish additional guidelines for security of collection sites.
  • Establishes the State Board of Elections will create standard vote by mail envelopes and provides guidelines for the creation of envelopes.

name: ELECTIONS-VARIOUS
categories: Voting equipment,In-person voting and polling places,Voter registration
summary:
• Defines electioneering.
  • Creates an Elections Special Projects Fund where all fees and penalties paid to the State Board of Elections will be deposited and used for ordinary and contingent expenses of the State Board of Elections.
  • Requires the appropriate election authority to notify candidates of the requirement to submit quarterly campaign contribution reports.
  • Prohibits anyone from circulating a nominating petition during an election within 100 feet of a polling place.
  • Removes guidelines related to contributions for political party committees.
  • Removes the requirement that the Task Force on Campaign Finance Reform make recommendations on improving access to information related to complaints.
  • Removes certain provisions related to the registration of business entities, including filing, timelines, reporting, and penalties. 
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to publish precinct-by-precinct vote totals for offices, candidates, and public questions with certified election results within 52 days of the election.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Replaces the term "measure" with "public question" or "question" in relevant legislation.
  • Replaces the term "Direct Recording Electronic Voting System" with "direct recording electronic tabulators and electronic marking devices" in relevant legislation.
  • Requires that direct recording electronic tabulators be capable of instantly marking votes, producing a permanent paper record, and enabling votes to be counted at the polling station, and further defines terms and capabilities of the equipment.
  • Prohibits use of public funds to sway a voter for or against anything or anyone on the ballot, or for political or campaign purposes.
  • Allows public funds to be used for "dissemination of factual information" related to voter education.
  • Outlines penalties for misuse of public funds or receipt of illegal contributions.
  • Outlines penalties for filing a false complaint.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to give political committees a blank form of the Code of Fair Campaign Practices and a copy of the related provisions.
  • Removes certain restrictions on political committees conducting raffles.
  • Outlines penalties for violating provisions related to political committees conducting raffles.

name: ELEC CD-REGISTRATION
summary:
• Allows certain forms at the department of motor vehicles to also be used as voter registration applications, provided the applicant presents identification confirming US citizenship and age, unless the applicant declines the option.
  • Provides that if an applicant to the department of motor vehicles does not submit identification confirming US citizenship and does not indicate the applicant is currently registered to vote in the state, then the application will not be a dual-purpose application.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to electronically transmit information to the State Board of Elections for each completed application, including the applicant's choice of language.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to enter into an agreement with certain agencies for the purpose of updating an applicant's existing voter registration record.
  • Allows the agencies to transmit information about clients who may be registered to vote for the sole purpose of updating their registration.
  • Requires the Department of Healthcare and Family Services to implement automatic voter registration for Medicaid applicants by July 1, 2023.
  • Establishes rules for automatic voter registration applications sent without signature.
  • Establishes procedures for automatic voter registration applications received for individuals protected by certain programs designed for confidentiality of victims.
  • Outlines certain notification requirements for individuals who are automatically registered to vote.
  • Makes other conforming changes to election code.

name: BOARD OF ELECTIONS APPOINTMENT
summary: • Establishes that the highest ranking State Senator of the political party not affiliated with the Governor will be the nominating officer for the State Board of Elections if all the state executive officers are in the same political party as the Governor.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL LIST
summary:
• Gives voters the option to be placed on the permanent vote by mail list.
  • Outlines processing requirements for being placed on the permanent vote by mail list and for processing ballots for elections.
  • Requires authorities to send a list of vote by mail voters to election officials within a certain timeline.
  • Clarifies that vote by mail ballots from permanent vote by mail voters are subject to the same deadlines and should be processed the same way as other ballots.
  • Outline procedures and notifications for voters who are on the permanent vote by mail list, but who do not return a ballot for four general elections.
  • Provides language for the vote by mail application, including a check box to indicate whether a voter wishes to be added to the permanent vote by mail list.
  • Outlines procedures for vote by mail partisan primaries in which a voter must choose a political party preference.
  • Outlines procedures for a voter to cancel their permanent vote by mail status, including listing what should be on the form.

name: ELEC CD-MAIL BALLOT
summary:
• Requires any campaign, party, or others engaging in vote by mail operations in which voters are sent applications by mail to also provide the voter with an addressed return envelope to the proper election authority.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: NOTARY PUB-NOMINATING PAPERS
summary: • Establishes that anyone who performs notarial acts related to election nominating papers, petitions of objection to nominating papers, or certificates of withdrawal of candidacy, and who is not authorized to provide notary services, will be in violation of the Election Code, in addition to other penalties.

name: ELECTIONS-NAME CHANGES
summary:
• Adds civil union to acceptable reasons for certification of a candidate name change.
  • Adds name change to conform to the candidate's gender identity as an acceptable reason for certification of a name change for a candidate.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a Voter Identification Card to registers voters who do not have an accepted form of photo ID.
  • Lists identifying items that must be on the Voter Identification Card.
  • The General Assembly intends to provide the Secretary of State guidance on how to issue the Voter Identification Card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide applications forms for the Voter Identification Card.
  • Lists documentation required for the Voter Registration Card and a non-photo identity document.
  • Provides exemptions for indigent voters and those with religious exemptions.
  • Lists acceptable forms of photo ID for voting.
  • Requires voters to verify their identity with appropriate ID.
  • Requires provisional voters to provide required ID within 10 days.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER IDENTIFICATION
categories: Cure provisions,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Signature matching
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to use a Voter Identification Card to each registered voter who does not have an acceptable form of photo ID, and includes information required on the card, valid dates, and uses.
  • Clarifies that the General Assembly intends to advise the Secretary of State on how to issue the identification card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for Voter Identification Cards and provide Cards to any registered voter who qualifies.
  • Lists documents requires for a Voter Identification Card.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification to be able to vote, including the Voter Identification Card.
  • Includes the Voter Identification Card in other related election ID rules.
  • Allows a provisional voter 10 days to provide the proper authority with required photo ID.
  • Outlines provisions and timetables for appointing judges to verify signatures on vote by mail ballots.
  • Lists reasons for rejecting a ballot due to signature verification, and procedures for notifying the voter and possibly offering an opportunity for a revote.

name: ELEC CD-PRE-REGISTRATION
summary:
• Replaces the "State Board of Elections website" with "electronic voter registration portal."
  • Allows qualified individuals to preregister to vote on or after their 16th birthday using the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows qualified individuals who are 17 years old, who will be 18 by the date of the next election to circulate a nominating petition or petition proposing a public question.
  • Deems qualified 16 year olds competent to execute and attest any voter registration forms.

name: ELECTION CODE-PETITIONS
summary:
• Changes the minimum age in nominating petitions from 18 to 17.
  • Changes the minimum age for signatories for a nominating petition from 18 to 17.

name: ELEC CD-TOWNSHIP CAUCUS
summary: • Includes vacancies in nomination occurring on or after a caucus in vacancy procedures.

name: ELEC CODE-EARLY VOTE PARKING
summary: • Requires election authorities to provide designated free parking during early voting at any permanent polling location.

name: ELECT CODE-ELECTION JUDGES
summary:
• Allows an election authority to reduce the number of judges in an election precinct from five to three for any election.
  • Makes complying changes to electoral code.

name: ELECTIONS-SENATE VACANCY-PARTY
summary:
• Requires anyone appointed to fill a vacancy for US Senate to be of the same political party as the person vacating the seat.
  • Requires that the appointee establish his or her political party affiliation by his or her record of voting in primary elections, or by holding office in a political party organization before the appointment.

name: ELEC CD-PETITION SIGNATURES
summary:
• Requires a petition for a candidate for State Senator to have 500-2,500 valid signatures.
  • Requires a petition for a candidate for State Representative to have 250-1,000 valid signatures.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
summary:
• Requires one elector from each congressional district for the purpose of election a US President and Vice President.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee to choose two at-large electors.
  • Applies this rule to existing procedures.
  • Requires that each congressional district elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won in their congressional district.
  • Requires that each at-large elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won the statewide race.

name: ELECT CODE-MAIL BALLOTS
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum)
summary:
• Requires election authorities to have a valid application to mail a ballot to a voter.
  • Prohibits election authorities from developing a program for mass mailing voter applications for ballots without first gaining approval from the electorate of the jurisdiction in a referendum.
  • Outlines requirements for the proposition process, language to be used, and procedures based on the results.

name: ELECT CODE-VOTE BY MAIL
most_recent_action: House Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 19(c) / Re-referred to Rules Committee
categories: Drop-box availability,In-person voter assistance,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Provides that it is the intent of the General Assembly to provide guidance on processing voters who do not have acceptable photo ID.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and establish procedures for identity verification.
  • Adds the Voter Identification Card as an acceptable form of photo ID for voting.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER REGISTRATION
summary: • Allows election authorities to access a landlord's tenant information to verify a voter registration, by paying a fee to the landlord.

name: ELEC CODE-PETITION SIGNATURES
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary:
• Requires that to form a new political party, signatures are needed from 5,000-10,000 qualified voters in the state following redistricting.
  • Requires a newly forming political party to get signatures from at least 600 qualified voters in a legislative district following redistricting.
  • Requires a newly forming political party to get signatures from at least 0.5% of qualified voters  in a county board district or municipal ward following redistricting.
  • Requires that signature requirements for new parties be the sane as for established parties after the effective date of the legislation.
  • Requires that signature requirements for independent candidates be the same as for established parties.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
summary:
• Requires one elector from each congressional district for the purpose of election a US President and Vice President.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee to choose two at-large electors.
  • Applies this rule to existing procedures.
  • Requires that each congressional district elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won in their congressional district.
  • Requires that each at-large elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won the statewide race.

name: ELECTION DAY HOLIDAY
summary:
• Adds general election day as a state holiday and makes complying changes.
  • Establishes general election day as the first Tuesday in November.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes non substantive changes to election code.

name: ELEC CD-DISABILITY/BALLOTS
summary:
• Defines "electronic ballot marking tool."
  • Clarifies that it is the intent of the General Assembly to make vote by mail fully accessible to disabled voters.
  • Requires development and implementation of procedures and technologies to provide vote by mail ballots in alternative formats to disabled voters that allow them to independently vote. Specifies specific related requirements.
  • Requires development of alternate methods to return ballots, including secure email portals, with certain specifications and requirements.
  • Requires each election authority to provide the option of fully electronic ballot and return that allows voters with disability to vote a secret ballot by January 1, 2023.

name: ELECTIONS-VARIOUS
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,Certification,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a system for the publication and certification of election results.
  • Requires the county clerk or election commissioners to quarterly confirm deceased voters and change of address voters, and to cancel registrations as appropriate.
  • Requires county clerks to update vote totals at least every 24 hours after election day and enumerates what must be included in the totals.

name: ELEC CD-PERMANENT VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
• Allows voters to apply to be added to a list of permanent vote by mail voters.
  • Requires permanent vote by mail voters to stay on the vote by mail list until they change their registration, request to be removed, or if the election authority receives notice that they are registered in another county.
  • Requires election authorities to notify qualified voters about the option of being placed on the permanent vote by mail list 45-90 days before an election, with certain requirements.
  • Provides language for the application for a permanent vote by mail application.
  • Requires election authorities to allow permanent vote by mail voters to change their party affiliation for a primary election.
  • Requires the vote by mail form to clearly distinguish between the permanent vote by mail option and the option for a single election.

name: ELEC CD-MAIL BALLOT/DISABILITY
summary:
• Defines "electronic transmission" and "voter with a disability."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish a procedure to sent vote by mail ballots electronically to persons with disability so that they can privately mark their ballot using assistive technology.
  • Requires the election authority to transmit a vote by mail ballot for a voter with disability within two business days if the application arrives after the election authority begins transmitting ballots.
  • Requires ballots received and marked to be printed by the voter and returned to the election authority.
  • Allows election authorities to deliver an official ballot electronically in certain instances.
  • Requires election authorities to provide voters with electronically transmitted ballots to provide the same instructions, certifications, and balloting materials as for other voters, to the extent possible.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTER ROLLS/CENSUS
summary: • Requires the State Board of Elections to provide for a process to reconcile the results of the 2020 U.S. Census with voter registration rolls.

name: ELEC CD-AUDIT FOR CAUSE
summary:
• Requires the treasurer of a political committee to preserve all records and accounts for two years before January 1, 2022, and seven years after that date.
  • Adds cause for the Board to order an audit of a political committee, including: sworn testimony in a guilty plea of a candidate or officer, conviction related to misuse of political committee funds, filing a statement of organization with a same officer or candidate who was in a political committee that was administratively terminated in the last 24 months.
  • Creates an audit period of seven years.

name: CITIZENS EMPOWERMENT ACT
summary:
• Creates the Citizen Empowerment Act.
  • Provides for the dissolution of a unit of local government by voters.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Outlines the steps for a petition for a referendum to dissolve a local government unit, including ballot placement.
  • Outlines voting requirements for the referendum.
  • Provides for the transfer of rights and duties with the dissolution of a unit of local government.
  • Includes the Citizen Empowerment Act in other electoral code.

name: JUDICIAL ELECTION/RETENTION
summary: • Establishes that no judge or former judge may submit a candidacy for a vacant judicial office by any method other than seeking retention in his or her office, unless the person is seeking judicial office in a higher or lower court, or if the person has served as a judge for at least two years.

name: ELEC CD-QUARANTINE
summary: • Adds voters in quarentine to those entitled to a hand delivered vote by mail ballot.

name: ELEC CD-RANKED CHOICE VOTING
summary:
• Provides that ranked choice voting be used for candidates for General Assembly, Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, Secretary of State, Comptroller, and Treasurer during regular and special elections.
  • Outlines ballot content rules for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines rules for voting a ranked choice ballot.
  • Outlines tallying procedures and rules for ranked choice voting.

name: ELEC CD-BODY CAMERAS
summary: • Requires all election judges and poll watchers to be equipped with body cameras and to record all their duties in the role.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL LIST
summary:
• Allows voters to apply to be added to a list of permanent vote by mail voters.
  • Outlines administrative procedures for election authorities receiving permanent vote by mail applications.
  • Requires mail in ballot applications to include a section to mark whether an applicant wishes to vote by mail for a single election or all future elections, with qualifying language and rules.
  • Outlines a procedure and language for cancellation of permanent vote by mail status.

name: COM COL-CHICAGO-ELECT BOARD
summary:
• Changes the name of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.
  • Requires in the 2022 primary that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and the Illinois Community College District 508 be elected in a non partisan election for a term of five years, with successors being elected for a term of four years.
  • Requires that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and Illinois Community College District 508 be elected at each consolidated election starting in April 2023 to succeed incumbent members whose term ends after the consolidated election.
  • Outlines board appointments, elections, membership, size, and vacancy procedures for community college districts.
  • Establishes language for nomination petitions, as well as instructions for content, processing, and timelines, in the City of Chicago.
  • Outlines rules for ballots and petitions related to community college district elections.
  • Requires the City of Chicago to create 20 trustee districts by January 1, 2022 and requires they be reapportioned the year after the decennial census.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
most_recent_action: Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Mattie Hunter
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes a non-substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes non-substantive change to election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes a non-substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes a non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: Mskrd

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Non-substantive change to the election code.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Makes non-substantive change to the election code.

name: Redistricting local election districts.
summary:
• Requires redistricting after the decennial census to occur in certain years for certain bodies: for a county or school corporation, in the first year after the census; for municipalities it depends on the year it conducts its elections.
  • Outlines certain deadlines for redistricting after a decennial census.
  • Outlines other timelines for conducting redistricting and prohibits redistricting at other times.
  • Clarifies when an area is required to redistrict.
  • Clarifies what to do if conflicts exist or if a territory is not included.
  • Changes population sizes for areas not subject to the standard redistricting rules.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Elections.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Audits,Oversight and accountability,Enforcement against non-officials,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary:
• Allows the election division to call a meeting under certain circumstances.
  • Requires the director, assistant director, or co-director of the board of elections to attend these meetings if they are called.
  • Provides that a member of a county election board may attend the meeting.
  • Outlines provisions for meetings held by the election division in a primary election year, including per diem and other reimbursements.
  • Allows county election officials to perform post-election audits.
  • Allows voters with print disabilities to vote by electronic mail or fax.
  • Establishes that a voter voting more than one ballot, except in certain circumstances, is commiting a felony.

name: Electronic voting machines.
categories: Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Audits,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Early voting administration,Provisional ballots
summary:
• Provides that this bill applies only if the costs can be paid from federal government funds or appropriated by the general assembly.
  • Requires certain information be used on the envelope for an absentee ballot application, including font size.
  • Requires the electronic poll book must have the capacity for each voter to transmit information if the voter cast a provisional ballot, through a private server to the statewide voter registration system.
  • Requires this function not be disabled.
  • Removes the provision that the circuit court clerk must provide notice to a voter who casts a provisional ballot.
  • Makes changes aligning current election code with new requirements.
  • Defines "early voting" to mean voting before an absentee voter board.
  • Enumerates circumstances in which a county election board will not use a direct record electronic voting system in an election after July 1, 2022.
  • Allows a county election board to use a module of the computerized list to comply with requirements for provisional voters.
  • Lists required elements in a county's list related to provisional ballots.
  • Defines "post election audit" and replaces the term "risk limiting audit" in related legislation.

name: Election of school board members.
summary:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Provides that the following rules apply only for nonpartisan school board elections.
  • Provides that nominees may withdraw by noon on July 15 under if nominations followed certain codes.
  • Removes candidates for precinct committeeman, state convention delegate, and school board from the requirement that names on ballot be arranged in alphabetical order.
  • Aligns relevant election code.
  • Removes school board elections from the list of elections where a candidate may receive the greatest number of votes to win.
  • Puts school board candidates on the ballot behind the town council candidates with certain provisions.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes in school board elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Removes conflicting code regarding vacancies and makes clarifying changes.
  • Clarifies rules governing nomination to be a candidate of a governing body.
  • Provides that these rules do not apply to school corporations with an elected school advisory board.
  • Amends the population size requirements of cities in adoption of certain membership increases of the governing body of the school corporation.

name: Description of political subdivisions.
summary:
• Names political subdivisions described by certain population parameters and other identifying features.
  • Changes formulas used to determine distribution of funds.
  • Removes provisions regarding the timeline for certain political subdivisions to take effect, as they relate to the decennial census.

name: Various elections matters.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Audits,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Early voting administration,Provisional ballots
summary:
• Provides that this bill applies only if the costs can be paid from federal government funds or appropriated funds from the general assembly.
  • Extends the term of the threat intelligence code to expire January 1, 2028, from January 1, 2023.
  • Requires certain information and format on the envelope for an absentee ballot application.
  • Allows that someone can register on election day if they meet certain requirements.
  • Removes the provision that the circuit court clerk must provide notice to a voter who casts a provisional ballot.
  • Lists reasons a voter would be permitted to vote by mail.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Clarifies that voting before an absentee voter board is "early voting."
  • Defines "post election audit" and replaces the term "risk limiting audit" with "post election audit" in related code.
  • Requires those accessing absentee ballot applications to provide certain identification.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Education
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Audits,States of emergency,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
• Prohibits the election commission from instituting, increasing, or expanding vote by mail or absentee ballot voting.
  • Prohibits the election commission from changing the time, manner, or place of holding an election.
  • Allows additionally a ten digit Indiana drivers license number or last four digits of the Social Security number for absentee ballot application identification.
  • Requires the county election board to deny an absentee ballot application if it does not include either the driver's license number or last four digits of the social security number, or if the numbers given do not match the election board's file.
  • Repeals the abilities of the secretary of state to designate counties as risk limiting pilot counties.
  • Requires the county election board to conduct a risk limiting audit before results are certified.
  • Specifies that the governor does not have the power to create an executive order changing the time, manner, or place of elections.
  • Specifies that the governor does not have the authority to institute or increase absentee voting or voting by mail.

name: Poll hours; same day registration.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Defines relevant terms.
  • Allows an individual to register or transfer registration on election day.
  • Makes changes to align new rules to current election code.
  • Enumerates requirements for registering on election day, including the responsibilities of relevant officials.
  • Establishes that an individual can register to vote until the close of polls on election day.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Audits,States of emergency,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
• Forbids the Commission from instituting or increasing vote by mail or absentee voting, or from changing the time, manner, or place of elections. 
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification for absentee ballot applications.
  • Provides that the county board of elections will deny an absentee ballot application if a voter does not include the required ID.
  • Outlines certain deadlines for submitting an absentee ballot application.
  • Lists pilot counties for an electronic voting system audit pilot program.
  • Provides that the secretary of state will enter into contracts to conduct the pilot audits of equipment used in the 2022 general election.
  • Sets expiration and other deadlines.
  • Provides that before the audit, the contractor will randomly select counties to be audited, with certain provisions.
  • Outlines certain contracting guidelines for the secretary of state.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the audit of computer equipment.
  • Clarifies that this code does not grant the governor the power to create an executive order changing the time, manner, or place of elections, nor does it grant the governor the authority to institute or increase vote by mail or absentee voting.

name: School board elections.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures,Election dates and administrative deadlines,Ballot access deadlines,Redistricting process
summary:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Provides that someone running for school board who wishes to be in the party primary election must file a declaration of candidacy.
  • Provides dates and deadlines for declaring candidacy for school board in 2022 primary elections and offers guidelines for ballots in the primary election.
  • Makes conforming changes for partisan school board elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes and filling vacancies in school board elections.
  • Outlines guidelines for candidate filing for school corporations and advisory boards, and clarifies that IC3 governs the nomination and election process.
  • Changes population requirements for dealing with ties and vacancies in school boards. 
  • Provides guidelines for candidate nominations in governing bodies.
  • Provides guidelines for vacancy of various governing board members.
  • Provides that a superintendent may hold a bachelor's degree in business administration.

name: Nomination of candidates.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary:
• Adds US Senators to the list of those requiring a state nominating convention to be a party candidate, as appropriate.
  • Clarifies that if no party candidate for US Senate gets a majority of votes, the election division must certify the candidate who received the greatest number of votes, with other associated actions.
  • Makes aligning changes to the election code.

name: Election computer equipment audit.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary:
• Lists pilot counties for the audit of computer equipment.
  • Requires the secretary of state to enter into contracts to conduct an audit of all computer equipment used in the 2022 general election in the pilot counties.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the contractee.
  • Outlines requirements for the audit, including reporting.
  • Establishes that the report must be submitted before December 31, 2022 to the secretary of state, attorney general, and chairs of the relevant senate and house committees.
  • Provides an expiration date.

name: Absentee voting.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary:
• Repeals the requirement that each inspector, judge, poll clerk, and election sheriff who is a voter of the county and not a resident of the precinct is entitled to an absentee ballot.
  • Repeals the code allowing nonresident challengers or pollbook holders to vote by absentee ballot.
  • Requires the computerized list to include absentee ballot management features, specifying certain requirements.
  • Requires the computerized list include documentation of the date each absentee ballot is issued and returned, and permits printing of absentee ballot applications with certain specifications.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the report of absentee ballot applications and voting.
  • Allows absentee ballot voters to vote by mail or before an absentee voter board.
  • Removes the requirement that an absentee ballot voter state the reason he or she is entitled to vote absentee.

name: Absentee voting.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Early voting administration
summary:
• Details a statement to be printed on absentee ballot envelope applications, including the font.
  • Prohibits anyone sending an absentee ballot unless it is requested by the individual.
  • Specifies forms of ID to be included with an absentee ballot application and requires a statement on the form that the application will be denied if the ID numbers do not match at least one that is on record.
  • Entitles a voter to vote by mail if they expect to be absent from the county or precinct for the entire period of time where a voter may vote absentee in-person, and on election day; or for the following additional reasons: if the voter will be confined, or observing a religious discipline during the entire absentee in-person voting period and election day.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Ballot access for minor parties.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary:
• Defines "major political party."
  • Allows major political parties to nominate party candidates for US Senate, US House of Representatives, Governor, legislative office, local office.
  • Requires nomination petitions to have at least 250 registered voter signatures from the election district.
  • Defines other political parties as those who received at least 2,500 votes but less than 25% of votes cast for at the last election for that office.

name: Automatic voter registration.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary:
• Clarifies that a person's signature on a department of motor vehicles application is considered the person's signature on their voter registration application.
  • Requires the bureau of motor vehicles commission to design, jointly with the election division, an application form to include the information required for a voter registration application for a driver's license.
  • Provides changes to align the new rules.
  • Outlines requirements of what should be included in the application for a driver's license, permit, or ID card/voter registration, and how it should be processed.
  • Requires officials to explain to driver's license applicants that if they do not decline to register to vote on their application, they will be considered to have selected the option to register, and that they meet eligibility requirements.

name: School board elections.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Requires school board candidates to follow the same procedures as other candidates for local office.
  • Provides that political parties may nominate candidates for school board in primary elections.
  • Aligns election code to include school board candidates in partisan elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes in school board elections.
  • Clarifies that election code IC3 governs the nomination and election of candidates in school board and advisory board elections and outlines specific procedures.
  • Removes conflicting code regarding vacancies and makes clarifying changes.
  • Clarifies rules governing nomination to be a candidate of a governing body.

name: School board elections.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary:
• Defines "school board" and includes elected school advisory board int he term.
  • Establishes that those who wish to run in a primary election of a political party for school board must file a declaration of candidacy.
  • Outlines signature requirements for school board nominations, based on population size.
  • Establishes that a candidate for school board who does not identify with a political party is an independent candidate.
  • Provides that a school board candidates political party affiliation should be listed on the ballot.
  • Outlines requirements for a candidate being affiliated with a political party.
  • Outlines the process of a challenge.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Establishes procedures for a tie vote and for filling vacancies on the school board and governing body.
  • Outlines provisions for election of members of the governing body.
  • States that IC3 governs the nomination and election of candidates.
  • Establishes nominating deadlines.
  • Clarifies that the state board will work with the assistance of the county election board to carry out the election.

name: Prohibition of firearms at polling places.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Corrections and Criminal Law
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Enforcement against non-officials
summary:
• Prohibits anyone from carrying a firearm within 50 feet of the chute, the polls, or wherever voters congregate to vote.
  • Prohibits anyone from carrying a firearm where ballots are being counted.
  • Provides that violation is a Class C misdemeanor, or other level misdemeanor or felony, under certain circumstances.
  • Lists reasons that are not a defense for bringing a firearm to the election site.
  • Requires election officials to conspicuously display a firearm prohibition in certain locations.
  • Outlines what should be included in the firearm prohibition notice.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: School board elections.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Education and Career Development
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures,Nonpartisan elections,Redistricting process
summary:
• Provides certain requirements to qualify as a candidate for school board.
  • Allows school board candidates to declare party affiliation if they wish, and provides for it to be listed on the ballot.
  • Makes related changes to unify the election code.
  • Provides for challenges to a candidates petition based on party affiliation.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes and filling vacancies on the school board.
  • Outlines certain guidelines for school board reorganization plans, including the provision that they will be elected, as required by law.
  • Requires community school corporations being created out of existing corporations be elected.
  • Provides conforming changes to election code.
  • Outlines guidelines for filing for election in a school corporation governing body.
  • Lists officials who may appoint a school corporation governing body member.
  • Clarifies that election code IC3 governs the nomination and election of candidates for governing board or school board.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Changes population requirements for governing board membership size.
  • Provides effective dates.
  • Provides that the county election board will assist the state board in administering school board elections.
  • Provides terms of office for school board members.

name: Absentee voting for the elderly and disabled.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary:
• Provides that elderly voters and voters with disabilities may apply for permanent absentee voter status.
  • Provides that a voter with permanent absentee voter status has the same rights and is subject to the same standards and procedures as other absentee voters.
  • Outlines responsibilities of the circuit court clerk if a voter qualifies for permanent absentee voter status.
  • Outlines processing instructions and notifications for permanent absentee voter's ballot. 
  • Outlines procedures for if more than one ballot is received by the election authorities.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Authorizing voter registration for individuals 16 years of age or older.
summary:
• Allows anyone 16 and older to apply to register to vote. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to suspend an applicants registration until they are 18 years of age, at which time they can vote.

name: Removing the option of extension of the time for receipt of advance mail ballots after the third day following an election.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary: • Removes the option for the secretary of state to extend the time limit deadline for mailed ballots.

name: Requiring a county election officer to send a confirmation of address when there is no election-related activity for any four calendar year period.
summary: • Requires a county election officer to send a confirmation of voter registration notice if a voter has not had an election-related activity in four calendar years.

name: Requiring audits of any federal, statewide or state legislative race that is within 1% of the total votes cast and requiring randomized audits of elections procedures used in four counties in even-numbered years.
summary:
• Requires an audit of all federal or state elections in even-numbered years that are within 1% of the vote.
  • Requires the audit to be in 10% of county precincts, with a minimum of one precinct per county.

name: Decreasing penalties for certain voting crimes and making amendments to the elements of the substantive offenses.
summary:
• Decreases the penalty for a series of crimes associated with advance voting ballots and applications from a level 9 felony to a class C misdemeanor.
  • Removes a provision in election bribery crimes excluding businesses or organizations.
  • Revises the definition of "voting without being qualified" to include voting or offering to vote more than once in the same election, and inducing another person to vote more than once, and revises penalties to make it a class A misdemeanor rather than a level 7 penalty.
  • Increases the penalty for election tampering from a level 7 felony to a level 8 felony.
  • Increases the penalty for false impersonation of a voter from a level 8 felony to a level 9 felony.
  • Makes clarifying changes to the language for the registration book declaration.

name: Requiring the secretary of state and local election officers to develop an affidavit to be signed by election workers regarding handling of completed ballots.
summary:
• Requires each person handling ballots for the county election office to sign an affidavit with certain information.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to develop an affidavit system that applies to all ballots handled at county election offices.
  • Establishes that violation of the affidavit is a level 9 felony.

name: Providing for the use of electronic poll books in elections and the approval of such books by the secretary of state, making fraudulent use of electronic poll books a crime, prohibiting electronic voting systems or electronic poll books from having the capability of connecting to the internet, requiring election judges to check for any such connection and providing a deadline for post-election voting equipment testing and for notice of such testing on county websites.
summary:
• Defines "electronic poll book" and provides exceptions.
  • Adds electronic poll books as an option, along with electromechanical voting system, for county commissioners and election officers at voting places.
  • Forbids electronic poll books or electromechanical voting systems from having the capability to connect to the internet or to a computer network.
  • Forbids the county election officer from buying or renting poll books unless they are certified by the Secretary of State.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to certify electronic poll books for internet safety related issues and outlines the process.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requiring that advance voting ballots be returned to the county election office by the day of the election.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes
summary:
• Requires advance voting ballots to be received by 7:00pm on election day.
  • Forbids anyone from changing the deadline.

name: Requiring all advanced voting ballots be returned by 7 p.m. on election day.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes
summary: • Requires that advance voting ballots be received by 7:00pm on election day.

name: Restrictions on third party solicitations to registered voters to file an application for an advance voting ballot.
summary:
• Requires those soliciting voters to file advance voting applications to conspicuously identify themselves in specified font on the envelope.
  • Requires any included envelopes be addressed to the office of the Secretary of State or county election office.

name: Requiring all voting systems for elections to use individual voter-verified paper ballots.
categories: Voting equipment,Audits,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Requires all voting systems in the state to use "individual, durable, voter-verified paper ballot" with certain required guidelines.
  • Provides for ballot counting and audits of the paper ballots.
  • Provides procedures for recounts.
  • Prohibits use of poll books without signatures.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to implement these rules.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requiring the secretary of state and county election officers to develop a ballot system showing the number of years an incumbent has served in the office.
summary: • Requires the Secretary of State and county election officers to develop a ballot system that includes how many years an incumbent candidate has served in the office.

name: Enacting the national popular vote interstate compact for electing the president of the United States.
summary:
• Enacts an interstate compact to elect the president by national popular vote.
  • Requires each state to conduct a statewide popular vote for US president and vice president.
  • Requires the chief election official to determine the popular vote in each state and produce a national popular vote total.
  • Requires the chief state election official to designate the presidential slate with the largest national popular vote total as the national popular vote winner, and to appoint electors accordingly. 
  • Outlines further requirements for: administration of the vote, the event of a tie, other administrative situations.
  • Requires the agreement to take effect when states with a majority of the electoral votes enact the agreement.
  • Outlines actions in the case of a state withdrawal.
  • Includes conforming changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Requiring county election officers to ensure electronic data and digital images of ballots are protected from physical or electronic alteration or destruction and making digital images of ballots open records and searchable by precinct.
summary:
• Requires county election officers to ensure electronic election data and images of ballots are protected from alteration, destruction, and unauthorized transfer, using protective measures at least as protective as those for paper ballots.
