  • Decreases the minimum number of votes for a party to have received in the last election from 130,000 to 50,000 or two percent of total votes for governor, whichever is less (rather than whichever is greater).
  • Provides that signatures will be collected during a 12 week period, and provides specific dates.
  • Changes the time range when the nominating petition is to be filed from 23-24 weeks before the election to 6-23 weeks before the election.
  • Changes the time for a certification of nomination to be made from thirty days after the June primary to seven weeks before the general election.

name: Relates to the number of signatures for independent nominating petitions; decreases the number of signatures and votes to 15,000 signatures for statewide candidates and 50,000 votes to maintain party ballot status; changes the petition period to 12 weeks and the petitioning time to May-August.
summary:
• Decreases the number of voters required to sign an independent nominating petition for state-level candidates from 45,000 to 15,000, and decreases the number of those signees who must live in half of the congressional districts from 500 to 100.
  • Decreases the number of required votes required to create a party from 130,000 at the last election for governor to 50,000, or two percent, whichever is less (a change from whichever is greater, which was the previous Code).
  • Stipulates that signatures for an independent petition for a general election will be collected for a 12-week period from the Monday before Memorial Day to the third Monday of August.
  • Changes the timeline for filing a petition for independent nomination from 23-24 weeks before the election to 6-23 weeks before the election.
  • Changes the deadline for filing a certificate of party nomination not made at a primary to seven weeks before the general election, rather than 30 days after the June primary.

name: Provides voting materials in French and Creole; requires translators in French and Creole in the city of New York at polling places in subdivisions where more than five percent of the citizens of voting age speak the language of French and/or Creole and are limited-English proficient.
summary:
• Requires boards of elections in cities with over one million people to provide voter information in French and Creole.
  • Requires New York City officials to provide ballots and voter support in French and Creole if 5% or more of voting age citizens in the district are limited-English proficient and speak one of the two languages.

name: Requires a new party to file a certificate following the election at which the party obtains party status.
summary: • Requires a new party to file a first certificate by the last day of February after the election where the party gained party status.

name: Provides that the police commissioner of the city of New York and all other cities with a population of one hundred thousand or more shall be an elected office with a four-year term; provides that such office shall be subject to term limits of two terms.
summary:
• Provides that the office of police commissioner will be elected in every city with a population greater than 100,000, but less than one million.
  • Provides that the term of office will be four years and provides for dates of election.
  • Provides that the police commissioner may be removed or suspended the same way as the mayor.
  • Establishes rules for filling a vacancy in office for police commissioner, for scheduling related elections, and for the newly chosen police commissioner taking office.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires the board of elections to mail notice of ensuing primary and general elections, registration status, polling place location and other information to active voters between the third Tuesday in April and the second Friday in May each year.
summary: • Change the timeline for mailing notification of polling hours 65-70 days before a primary election to between the third Tuesday in April and the second Friday in May.

name: Authorizes United States citizens currently residing outside the United States whose last residence in the United States was in the state of New York to vote in certain federal elections.
summary: • Removes US territories from the list of locations where a citizen may be registered to vote.

name: Makes commissioners full time employees of the board.
summary: • Provides that election commissioners will be full time employees of the board.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Presidential elections,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Adds presidential elections, in addition to existing gubernatorial elections, to ballot format guidelines regarding which party will be in column A or one.
  • Provides that for judicial district conventions the number of delegates for a new party will be based on the party's vote for presidential electors, and thereafter be based on the party's vote for Governor.
  • Adds the office of president of the United States to the list of office where someone running for an office may appear as many times as they are nominated.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to special elections to fill vacancies in the state senate and assembly and certain deadlines with regard to such special elections.
categories: Special election procedures,Vacancy procedures,Election dates and administrative deadlines
summary:
• Creates separate guidelines for filling a vacancy for state senate or assembly.
  • Adds deadlines for determining nominations, certificate of party nomination, certificate of acceptance, and authorizing certificates for special elections.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for objections to certificate of nomination or other specified certificates in a special election.
  • Provides that early voting places must operate 30 days before a special election.
  • Provides timelines for ballots for military voters in a special election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Makes the suppression of voters a civil violation.
summary: Makes deceptive practices and voter suppression of voters a civil violation. Deceptive practices is defined as knowingly communicating or knowingly causing to be communicated deceptive information, such as election information known to be false, and thus preventing or deterring another person from exercising the right to vote in any election. Suppression is defined as the use force, authority or an abuse of power to prevent, restrain, inhibit or compel another from acting in his or her own interests or intentions.

name: Requires county committees to meet for the purposes of organization after the certification of the June primary at which the members of such committee are elected but no later than October sixth following the June primary.
categories: Ballot access for parties,Ballot access deadlines
summary: • Requires every county committee to meet no earlier than one day after the June primary is certified, instead of by September 17.

name: Relates to furnishing money or entertainment to induce attendance at polls.
summary: • Prohibits distributing anything with a nominal value at a polling place or in the line to vote.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to notify voters the their district may have changed due to redistricting.
  • Provides guidance on what should be included in the program.

name: Requires voters to provide a current and valid social security number when casting a ballot to vote.
summary:
• Requires the voter to provide his or her social security number when registering to vote.
  • Provides that a copy of a voter's social security card allows the applicant to apply for an absentee ballot.

name: Requires that county committees meet no earlier than one day after the June primary is certified.
summary: • Changes the date for county committees to meet from September 17 to one day after the June primary is certified.

name: Relates to objections to designating and nominating petitions; outlines requirements for officers, boards and judges making determinations as to the sufficiency of a designating or nominating petition.
summary:
• Specifies that an officer or board should construe election laws liberally when ruling on objections to designating and nominating petitions.
  • Outlines required considerations for the officer or board in making a determination about the sufficiency of a petition.

name: Requires a new party to file a certificate following the election at which the party obtains party status.
summary: • Requires new parties to file a first certificate by the last day of February after the election where the party obtained party status.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of an election law related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from December 31, 2021 to April 1, 2022.

name: Prohibits municipal employees appointed by the chief executive officer of a municipality or the governing body of a municipality, who are not members of a collective bargaining unit, from serving as political party officers in any capacity; exempts municipal employees appointed by a school district or fire district.
summary:
• Prohibits municipal employees who are not part of a collecting bargaining unit from serving as political party officers, with certain exceptions.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to the time period during which absentee ballots shall be mailed or delivered after an application for such ballot is received by the board of elections.
summary:
• Provides timelines for mailing or delivering absentee ballots based on when the application was received.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Requires absentee ballots for fire district elections, including, but not limited to, all projects or mandatory, permissive or special referendums which require a vote by qualified residents of such fire district; provides that a qualified voter may vote as an absentee voter under certain circumstances and lays out such criteria; requires that an application must be received by the district clerk no earlier than the thirtieth day before the election for which an absentee ballot is sought; makes
summary:
• Requires boards of fire commissioners to provide for absentee ballots for elections.
  • Provides guidelines and timelines for absentee ballots.
  • Outlines timelines and procedures for mailing the absentee ballots.

name: Removes provisions requiring election inspectors, poll clerks, and election coordinators to be appointed in a bipartisan manner.
summary:
• Removes the requirement, and instead makes it recommended, that election inspectors and poll clerks are to be equally divided between the two major political parties at each polling place.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provides that a voter may register to vote at any residence to which the voter maintains a continuous connection with an intent to return, including a second home or a vacation home.
summary: • Allows someone to vote from a second or vacation home if they are registered at the residence and maintain a continuous connection with the intent to return.

name: Provides that a voter may register to vote at any residence to which the voter maintains a continuous connection with an intent to return, including a second home or a vacation home.
summary: • Allows voters to register and vote from a second or vacation home.

name: Provides that in 2022, the statement of party positions to be filled at a primary election shall be filed by February 28, 2022; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
summary: • Specifies that the statement of party positions for 2022 primary elections must be filed by February 28, 2022.

name: Includes within the class D felony of assault in the second degree, the intentional causing of physical injury to an election officer while such person is performing their assigned duties; amends aggravated harassment and obstruction of governmental administration to include election officers.
summary:
• Adds election officers to existing code prohibiting physical injury to certain government workers and penalties.
  • Specifies the code refers to harassing, annoying, threatening, alarming, and having physically contact with an election official while he or she tries to perform his or her duties.

name: Provides that an attorney licensed to practice in the state may serve as a poll watcher in any city or county in the state.
summary: • Specifies that existing election watcher code does not prohibit a licensed attorney who is a New York resident from visiting a polling place.

name: Relates to donate life registrations; changes the effectiveness to one year after it shall have become a law.
summary:
• Edits the list of forms where a person can choose to be an organ donor.
  • Changes the effective date.

name: Authorizes party designations and nominations for elections to be made via video conference upon notice to the members of the respective committee; allows certificates of designation or nomination to be executed in separate acts by the signatories.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill authorizes party designations and nominations for elections to be made via video conference upon notice to the members of the respective committee. The bill allows certificates of designation or nomination to be executed in separate acts by the signatories.

name: Prohibits an election district to be created, consolidated, divided or altered by the board of elections in 2021 in certain counties that made temporary amendments to its rules regarding the election of county committee members.
summary: • Prohibits creation, consolidation, division, or alteration of a county election district in 2021 if the county executive committee filed a temporary amendment to its rules related to election of county committee members.

name: Requires that all candidates obtain the written, express permission of any person identified in campaign literature.
summary: • Requires any campaign literature, advertisements, media broadcasts, public speeches, and other campaign writing identifying anyone other than the candidate, obtain the written permission of the person being identified.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary: • Requires the state board to create a program to notify voters about changes due to redistricting, and provides specific notification requirements.

name: Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for the prior election; provides for a permanent absentee ballot application list.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for village, primary, special, and general elections.
  • Requires the board of elections to establish a permanent absentee voter list.
  • Lists requirements for the permanent absentee voter list.

name: Authorizes voting by proxy at a judicial district convention due to novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
summary: This bill permits voting by proxy at a judicial district convention due to novel coronavirus, COVID-19.

name: Permits voting by absentee ballot where there is a risk of contracting or spreading a disease that may cause illness to the voter or to other members of the public.
summary:
• Defines "illness" in absentee voting.
  • Changes the expiration date of the code to December 31, 2022 from January 1, 2022.

name: Relates to special elections to fill vacancies in the state senate and assembly and certain deadlines with regard to such special elections.
summary:
• Separates the state senate and assembly from other entities for rules related to calling a special election due to a vacancy.
  • Specifies that the governor may set the same date for a vacancy election in the state senate or assembly with another existing special election, with certain requirements.
  • Adds a deadline of 24 days before special elections for the state legislature for certifying candidates.
  • Provides a deadline for special elections for the state legislature related to party certificates of nomination of candidates.
  • Provides rules for filing an objection to a certificate of party nomination, or other certificates, for a special election to the state legislature.
  • Provides deadlines for acceptance of a certificate of nomination for special elections to the state legislature, and provides deadlines for other certificates related to the nomination process.
  • Provides a timeline for early voting locations for a special election to the state legislature.
  • Provides a timeline for military voting in a special election to the state legislature.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Election dates and administrative deadlines
summary:
• Changes the effective date of codes related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from January 1, 2022 to April 1, 2022.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to the number of early voting poll sites in certain cities and towns; requires, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Provides that there must be at least one early voting polling place in cities and towns with a population between 100,000 and one million, and that there should be additional polling places for every 50,000 additional people, not to exceed 11 polling places.

name: Changes the effective date of bills numbers S.1027-A and A.7931 to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of this act regarding canvassing absentee, military, and special ballots from January to April 1, 2022.

name: Permits voting by absentee ballot where there is a risk of contracting or spreading a disease that may cause illness to the voter or to other members of the public.
summary:
• Defines illness in absentee voting to include someone who is at risk of contracting or spreading a disease.
  • Changes the expiration date from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022.

name: Relates to the number of early voting poll sites in certain cities and towns; requires, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
summary:
• Requires an early voting polling place in cities and towns with a population of 100,000-1,000,000.
  • Requires one polling place per 50,000 residents.
  • Sets element as a maximum number of required polling places.
  • Provides that polling places should be located on public transportation routes when possible.

name: Allows a judicial district convention to be conducted in whole or in part via video conference upon a minimum of seventy-two hours notice to the members of the respective committee by mail, an appropriately titled email, text or telephone call at an address or number expressly provided in writing for the purpose of receiving such notices.
summary:
• Authorizes a judicial district convention to be held via video conference with 72 hours notice.
  • Provides specific requirements for the notification.
  • Requires that the video conference portion afford the same opportunity to listen and to be heard as an in-person meeting.

name: Provides that whenever a contiguous property of a college or university contains three hundred or more registrants, the polling place designated for such election district shall be on such contiguous property or at a location approved by the college or university.
summary:
• Provides that if a property contiguous to a university has more than 300 active registered voters, those voters may vote at an address on the property, or at a location approved by the university.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Authorizes boards of elections to establish absentee ballot drop-off locations.
summary:
• Authorizes each board of elections to establish one or more absentee ballot drop-off locations, and includes notification requirements.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules for implementation of absentee ballot drop-off locations.
  • Specifies procedures and deadlines for receiving absentee ballots.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to the order in which candidates appear on the ballot; requires that offices shall be listed on the ballot in descending order based on the size of the electorate and requires certain federal offices to be listed before state, county or local offices.
summary:
• Requires that offices on a ballot be listed in order of precedence and lists the order of precedence for offices.
  • Provides that office other than those listed should appear in the customary order.
  • Requires partisan offices to appear on the ballot after nonpartisan offices.
  • Requires judicial offices to follow other partisan offices on the ballot.

name: Establishes portable polling locations for early voting; provides that a county board of elections may establish one or more portable polling locations.
summary:
• Establishes that a county board of elections may establish portable polling locations for early voting, based on numbers established by the state board of elections.
  • Outlines guidelines for the number and location of stations.
  • Prohibits replacement of existing early voting locations with portable locations.

name: Requires the board of elections in the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in a ranked choice election, even if a single candidate received a majority of highest rank votes and the tabulation process was not triggered.
summary: • Requires the board of election in New York City to release data on how voters ranked all candidates when using ranked choice voting.

name: Requires the board of elections in the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in a ranked choice election, even if a single candidate received a majority of highest rank votes and the tabulation process was not triggered.
summary: • Requires the board of election in New York City to release data on how voters ranked all candidates when using ranked choice voting.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary: • Requires that elections for municipal office in New York City be "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting systems.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary: • Requires that elections for municipal office in New York City be "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting systems.

name: Lowers the voting age to 16 years and requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.
summary:
• Lowers the voting age to 16 for any election.
  • Provides that a voter registration applicant must be 16 by December 31 of the year they register.
  • Requires all ninth and higher grades to have civic education with certain guidelines.
  • Provides instructions for registering high school students to vote at school.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Lowers the voting age to 16 years and requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.
summary:
• Lowers the voting age to 16 for any election.
  • Provides that a voter registration applicant must be 16 by December 31 of the year they register.
  • Requires all ninth and higher grades to have civic education with certain guidelines.
  • Provides instructions for registering high school students to vote at school.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: • Provides that in presidential election years an additional primary will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (was the first Tuesday in February).

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: • Provides that in presidential election years an additional primary will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (was the first Tuesday in February).

name: Relating to requests for absentee ballots.
summary: •  Changes the timespan for receiving absentee ballot applications from 7-30 days before the elections, to a simple deadline of 7 days before the election.

name: Relating to requests for absentee ballots.
summary: •  Changes the timespan for receiving absentee ballot applications from 7-30 days before the elections, to a simple deadline of 7 days before the election.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to mail an absentee ballot and return postage envelope to every qualified voter in the county or city.
  • Requires the ballots be mailed to the voter's registered address.
  • Provides specifications on deadlines.
  • Makes exceptions for uncontested elections.
  • Allows voters to request envelopes be mailed to a different address.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to mail an absentee ballot and return postage envelope to every qualified voter in the county or city.
  • Requires the ballots be mailed to the voter's registered address.
  • Provides specifications on deadlines.
  • Makes exceptions for uncontested elections.
  • Allows voters to request envelopes be mailed to a different address.

name: Requires the election of fire district commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members.
summary:
• Provides that election of fire district members will occur on the same date, and at the same location, as election of school board members in the municipality.
  • Requires that the Secretary of State of the fire district get approval of the board of elections to prepare ballots for the fire district elections.
  • Changes the opening hour for poll openings for the fire district elections from 6:00PM to 6:00AM.
  • Provides that all electoral procedures related to the fire district election will follow the same procedures as the school board elections.
  • Provides that costs for the election will be borne by the fire district.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires the election of fire district commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members.
summary:
• Provides that election of fire district members will occur on the same date, and at the same location, as election of school board members in the municipality.
  • Requires that the Secretary of State of the fire district get approval of the board of elections to prepare ballots for the fire district elections.
  • Changes the opening hour for poll openings for the fire district elections from 6:00PM to 6:00AM.
  • Provides that all electoral procedures related to the fire district election will follow the same procedures as the school board elections.
  • Provides that costs for the election will be borne by the fire district.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: • Provides that anyone who does not have the right to vote, or the right to register to vote, by the state constitution, also does not have the right to vote, or register to vote, locally.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: • Provides that anyone who does not have the right to vote, or the right to register to vote, by the state constitution, also does not have the right to vote, or register to vote, locally.

name: Allows poll workers to be from any political party.
summary: • Provides that if a political party does not have enough applicants for election inspector or poll clerk, appointments may be made of individuals who are not associated with any major party.

name: Allows poll workers to be from any political party.
summary: • Provides that if a political party does not have enough applicants for election inspector or poll clerk, appointments may be made of individuals who are not associated with any major party.

name: Relates to voting rights expansion, voter registration on election day, expansion of the use of and requirements for absentee voting, creation of a real-time statewide voter registration database, special ballots for election employees, and voter affidavits.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Allows qualified individuals to register to vote on Election Day and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows any voter to vote absentee and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows voters to have their absentee ballot mailed to an address other than their permanent address and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows hospitalized veterans to receive their absentee ballot at the address where they are registered to vote.
  • Provides that the board of inspectors will deliver absentee ballots to residents of certain facilities.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create a single official computerized statewide voter registration database within one year and provides associated guidelines and requirements.
  • Provides that absent proof of fraud, special ballots will be presumed valid and will be cast.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to voting rights expansion, voter registration on election day, expansion of the use of and requirements for absentee voting, creation of a real-time statewide voter registration database, special ballots for election employees, and voter affidavits.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Allows qualified individuals to register to vote on Election Day and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows any voter to vote absentee and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows voters to have their absentee ballot mailed to an address other than their permanent address and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows hospitalized veterans to receive their absentee ballot at the address where they are registered to vote.
  • Provides that the board of inspectors will deliver absentee ballots to residents of certain facilities.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create a single official computerized statewide voter registration database within one year and provides associated guidelines and requirements.
  • Provides that absent proof of fraud, special ballots will be presumed valid and will be cast.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Authorizes, under certain circumstances, full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located.
summary:
• Provides that a full time college student may act as an election inspector or poll clerk in the county of the location of the college, with exceptions for New York City.
  • Provides guidelines on questions the student must answer to be certified.
  • Defines "full time."

name: Authorizes, under certain circumstances, full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located.
summary:
• Provides that a full time college student may act as an election inspector or poll clerk in the county of the location of the college, with exceptions for New York City.
  • Provides guidelines on questions the student must answer to be certified.
  • Defines "full time."

name: Requires the canvass of absentee ballots as they are received.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Requires officials designated by the board to canvass absentee ballots as they are received.
  • Removes a deadline for notifying candidates and parties entitled to have watchers at the polls, and requires it be sent "prior to" receiving ballots.

name: Requires the canvass of absentee ballots as they are received.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Requires officials designated by the board to canvass absentee ballots as they are received.
  • Removes a deadline for notifying candidates and parties entitled to have watchers at the polls, and requires it be sent "prior to" receiving ballots.

name: Authorizes absentee ballots in an election to incorporate a village.
summary:
• Establishes that absentee ballots should be as similar as possible to ballots used on Election Day, but with the words "Absentee Ballot" written on them.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to the crimes of fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus or convention, and criminal impersonation in the first degree where a person pretends to be an elected official or candidate for an elected office and acts by impersonating such an elected official, or candidate or campaign for such an elected office, by communication by internet website or electronic means, with intent to obtain a benefit or injure or defraud another; requires social media companies to establish practi
summary:
• Adds impersonating an election office, candidate, or campaign to the list of crimes of fraud.
  • Lists what is considered fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus, or convention and establishes that the state board of elections has the authority to impose civil penalties on these violations.
  • Furnishes the state board of elections with the authority to seek injunctive relief, and investigative authority including subpoena powers, in cases of impersonation of an election official and other fraud.
  • Requires social media companies to close accounts within 24 hours where they receive complaints alleging first degree criminal impersonation or fraud.

name: Relates to the crimes of fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus or convention, and criminal impersonation in the first degree where a person pretends to be an elected official or candidate for an elected office and acts by impersonating such an elected official, or candidate or campaign for such an elected office, by communication by internet website or electronic means, with intent to obtain a benefit or injure or defraud another; requires social media companies to establish practi

  • Lists what is considered fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus, or convention and establishes that the state board of elections has the authority to impose civil penalties on these violations.
  • Furnishes the state board of elections with the authority to seek injunctive relief, and investigative authority including subpoena powers, in cases of impersonation of an election official and other fraud.
  • Requires social media companies to close accounts within 24 hours where they receive complaints alleging first degree criminal impersonation or fraud.

name: Allows for a voter to apply for an absentee ballot for any reason.
summary:
• Provides that a voter may request an absentee ballot for any reason.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Allows for a voter to apply for an absentee ballot for any reason.
summary:
• Provides that a voter may request an absentee ballot for any reason.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) for year two thousand twenty-one.
summary: • Provides that the number of signatures required on designating petitions and independent nominations for those diagnosed with COVID-19 will be reduced by one-third.

name: Decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) for year two thousand twenty-one.
summary: • Provides that the number of signatures required on designating petitions and independent nominations for those diagnosed with COVID-19 will be reduced by one-third.

name: Instructs the state board of elections to create and distribute voting guides to voters containing information about the candidates; mandates that voters receive postcards to notify them of upcoming elections and that television and radio stations also notify their audience of upcoming elections.
summary:
• Provides that a candidate may file a sworn statement with specific information for a voter guide created by the state board of elections.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for the state board of elections in creating the candidate guide.
  • Outlines procedures for distributing the candidate guide and maintaining a website with the information.
  • Requires the board to notify the public by television and radio of the existence of the guide, with specific requirements.

name: Establishes provisions requiring absentee ballots that do not have postmarked dates that are received in the mail by the board of elections within three days following the day of election to be cast and counted.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: • Requires an absentee ballot without any date markings indicating when it was mailed to be counted if it arrives to the board of elections by three days after the election.

name: Establishes provisions requiring absentee ballots that do not have postmarked dates that are received in the mail by the board of elections within three days following the day of election to be cast and counted.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: • Requires an absentee ballot without any date markings indicating when it was mailed to be counted if it arrives to the board of elections by three days after the election.

name: Requires voters voting by affidavit ballot to produce an identification document to verify residency in the election district; requires absentee ballots to be received by election day, or be post-marked by the first day of early voting.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
• Provides that a voter voting by affidavit ballot is required to produce specific identification, and provides related requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Adds a starting date of the first day of early voting to the time period for receiving absentee ballots.
  • Changes the last permissible day for receiving an absentee ballot to an office timestamp on the day of the election (instead of the day after the election).

name: Requires voters voting by affidavit ballot to produce an identification document to verify residency in the election district; requires absentee ballots to be received by election day, or be post-marked by the first day of early voting.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
• Provides that a voter voting by affidavit ballot is required to produce specific identification, and provides related requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Adds a starting date of the first day of early voting to the time period for receiving absentee ballots.
  • Changes the last permissible day for receiving an absentee ballot to an office timestamp on the day of the election (instead of the day after the election).

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Provides that an incarcerated voter will be considered a resident of the locale where he or she resided before incarceration.
  • Establishes that a voter's registration will not be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires establishment of a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting, and includes requirements.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:

  • Establishes that a voter's registration will not be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires establishment of a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting, and includes requirements.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide the public with free and timely access to updated absentee ballot data.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to post a running total of accepted and rejected absentee, military, and special ballots after a canvass.
  • Requires reasons to be posted for rejected ballots.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide the public with free and timely access to updated absentee ballot data.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to post a running total of accepted and rejected absentee, military, and special ballots after a canvass.
  • Requires reasons to be posted for rejected ballots.

name: Includes attempting to register as an elector knowing that he or she is not qualified due to lack of U.S. citizenship.
categories: Legal causes of action,Noncitizen voting,Voter registration
summary: This bill prohibits attempting to registering or attempting to register if the person is not qualified due to lack of U.S. citizenship.

name: Relates to restricting election day duties of board of elections employees in the city of New York running for elected party positions; provides that no board of elections employee in the city of New York shall engage in any election day operations or management within any assembly district in which he or she is also a candidate for an elected party position.
summary: This bill restricts election day duties of board of elections employees in the city of New York running for elected party positions and provides that no board of elections employee in the city of New York shall engage in any election day operations or management within any assembly district in which he or she is also a candidate for an elected party position.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary:
• Allows the option of using the highest number of votes for president in the last election, in addition to the option of using the highest number of votes for governor, when determining the order of candidates on a ballot.
  • Provides rules regarding number of delegates at a judicial district convention for newly formed political parties.
  • Provides rules regarding selecting election district delegates by county committee for newly formed political parties.
  • Adds the office of US President to the list of offices where a nominated candidate my appear multiple times on the ballot.
  • Provides rules for newly formed political parties regarding casting votes at the state committee for presidential electors.
  • Adds presidential electors to the list of offices the board of elections needs to transmit to the state board after a canvass.

categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties

name: Relates to the appointment of commissioners of elections; provides that once a party recommends a person for commissioner of elections the local legislative body shall automatically approve the appointment of such person.
summary:
• Provides that the legislature must automatically approve commissioners of elections recommended by a party.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to the appointment of commissioners of elections; provides that once a party recommends a person for commissioner of elections the local legislative body shall automatically approve the appointment of such person.
summary:
• Provides that the legislature must automatically approve commissioners of elections recommended by a party.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Authorizes additional days of voting as a result of emergencies; includes state of emergency.
summary:
• Adds a state of emergency to the list of reasons a county board of elections may consider for adding an additional day of voting.
  • Provides that notification must be given a week before the additional day of voting and specifies how the notification should be given.
  • Provides that a board of elections may change the date of a party caucus under certain circumstances and outlines guidelines and requirements for the change.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Authorizes additional days of voting as a result of emergencies; includes state of emergency.

  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.
summary:
• Requires a risk limiting audit after an election that includes a hand review of at least 3% of paper records.
  • Requires the board of elections to audit 3% of voting machine records.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules to implement risk limiting audit procedures.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.

name: Removes the requirement of a sworn statement administered by a notary public for purposes of petitions; requires the notary public to inquire whether the person is the same listed on the address.
summary:
• Changes the notary public statement to be used in place of a witness signature to ensure the notary inquires about the voter's current address.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Removes the requirement of a sworn statement administered by a notary public for purposes of petitions; requires the notary public to inquire whether the person is the same listed on the address.
summary:
• Changes the notary public statement to be used in place of a witness signature to ensure the notary inquires about the voter's current address.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires that candidates for certain offices be residents and registered voters in the district containing the public office or party position sought at certain times during the electoral process.
summary:
• Outlines residency requirements for candidates, including allowing localities to enact stricter requirements.
  • Specifies that a candidate for county committee must only be a resident of the Assembly district containing the election district.
  • Specifies candidates must be residents in the district by the time of the party caucus.
  • Specifies that failure to meet residency requirements renders a nomination void.
  • Exempts candidates for Congress, state assembly, state senate or judicial candidates for the Supreme Court from the specified district residency requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Authorizes boards of elections to establish absentee ballot drop-off locations.
summary:
• Defines terms related to absentee ballot drop boxes.
  • Authorizes each board of elections to establish absentee ballot drop box drop off locations, with specific requirements.
  • Authorizes the state board of elections to create rules and procedures for absentee ballot drop box implementation and security.
  • Allows voters to drop off absentee ballots in drop box in their city or county.
  • Establishes rules for drop off, collection, and counting deadlines.

name: Authorizes boards of elections to establish absentee ballot drop-off locations.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
summary:
• Allows certain groups to appoint up to two nonpartisan poll monitors per polling place.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for designating nonpartisan poll monitors, including authorizations, denials, and appeals.
  • Outlines polling place procedures for nonpartisan poll monitors.
  • Outlines the qualifications needed to be appointed a nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Provides the job responsibilities of the nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Provides for credentials for the nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Specifies that there will be no more than two nonpartisan poll monitors from any organization at a polling place at the same time and procedures for if there is more than one organization at the polling place.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to prohibiting election commissioners from being chairs of political parties.
summary: This bill prohibits a person from being appointed as Election Commissioner or continue to hold office who is the chair of a political organization in the county.

name: Relates to prohibiting election commissioners from being chairs of political parties.
summary: This bill prohibits a person from being appointed as Election Commissioner or continue to hold office who is the chair of a political organization in the county.

name: Requires the preparation of reports on assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks.
summary: • Provides that county boards of elections, and the city of New York, must prepare a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks and include vacancies that exist at poll sites.

name: Requires the preparation of reports on assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks.
summary: • Provides that county boards of elections, and the city of New York, must prepare a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks and include vacancies that exist at poll sites.

name: Authorizes persons in control of public school buildings to request the cancellation of the designation of such building as a polling place.
summary: • Removes public school buildings from being an exception in requirements for polling places in public buildings.

name: Authorizes persons in control of public school buildings to request the cancellation of the designation of such building as a polling place.
summary: • Removes public school buildings from being an exception in requirements for polling places in public buildings.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary: • Prohibits public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as an early voting location, with an additional provision for school buildings without instructional space.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary: • Prohibits public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as an early voting location, with an additional provision for school buildings without instructional space.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes election commissioners' terms of office from two to four years beginning February 15, instead of January 1, and removes provisions allowing county legislative bodies to do otherwise.
  • Allows county committees to recommend at least two additional people for appointment for commissioner of elections when there is a vacancy and the legislative body failed to appoint someone.
  • Provides instructions for removal of election commissioners and filling vacancies.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes election commissioners' terms of office from two to four years beginning February 15, instead of January 1, and removes provisions allowing county legislative bodies to do otherwise.
  • Allows county committees to recommend at least two additional people for appointment for commissioner of elections when there is a vacancy and the legislative body failed to appoint someone.
  • Provides instructions for removal of election commissioners and filling vacancies.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Relates to the appointment of election inspectors and poll clerks; requires the board of elections of each county to make appointments by April 15 of each year; provides that a person listed on an original or supplemental list of eligible persons to serve as election inspectors or poll clerks for three consecutive years must submit a written affirmation of willingness and availability to serve.
summary: • Provides that if someone on the political party list for election inspector, poll clerk, or election coordinator has not served in three years, the party must obtain a written statement affirming that the person is still willing to serve.

name: Relates to the appointment of election inspectors and poll clerks; requires the board of elections of each county to make appointments by April 15 of each year; provides that a person listed on an original or supplemental list of eligible persons to serve as election inspectors or poll clerks for three consecutive years must submit a written affirmation of willingness and availability to serve.
summary: • Provides that if someone on the political party list for election inspector, poll clerk, or election coordinator has not served in three years, the party must obtain a written statement affirming that the person is still willing to serve.

name: Eliminates the signature requirement for designating petitions for certain candidates for office in the city of New York.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: • Provides that there will be no signature requirement for a candidate receiving public matching funds in the city of New York.

name: Eliminates the signature requirement for designating petitions for certain candidates for office in the city of New York.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: • Provides that there will be no signature requirement for a candidate receiving public matching funds in the city of New York.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.
summary:
• Prohibits actions creating a conflict of interest for board of election employees including: investing in a company providing services to a candidate in that district, or investing in a company who is a vendor selling voting equipment.
  • Provides penalties.
  • Prohibits a board of elections employee from working for a candidate or being a candidate in the district holding the election.
  • Provides related "leave without pay" policies.
  • Provides that a candidate employed by the board of elections who is not running in a primary election may remain on the payroll for up to 90 days before the general election.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary:
• Directs each electoral college elector to cast their vote for president and Vice President for candidates nominated by the political party that nominated the elector.
  • Establishes that refusal will constitute a resignation and the vote will not be recorded, and a replacement will be named.
  • Requires ballots used by the elector to bear their name.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary:

  • Establishes that refusal will constitute a resignation and the vote will not be recorded, and a replacement will be named.
  • Requires ballots used by the elector to bear their name.

name: Relates to requiring boards of elections to include the number of registration forms distributed to and returned by each agency assisting with voter registration in their annual reports; personally identifiable information about the registrants shall not be collected or included in the report.
summary:
• Requires board of elections annual reports to include the number of registration forms distributed and returned.
  • Specifies that personal voter information must not be included in the report.

name: Relates to requiring boards of elections to include the number of registration forms distributed to and returned by each agency assisting with voter registration in their annual reports; personally identifiable information about the registrants shall not be collected or included in the report.

  • Specifies that personal voter information must not be included in the report.

name: Relates to making electronic ballot images and cast vote records public records of the board of elections upon request.
summary:
• Requires an electronic image of each cast ballot and each vote record be copied from the memory card no later than one week after the election.
  • Provides that these images are public records.

name: Prohibits political candidates from being nominated by more than one party for any public office.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: • Provides that a person cannot be nominated for public office or a party position if the person has already accepted another party's nomination for such position.

name: Increases the term of office of an election commissioner from two to four years beginning January first of each odd numbered year.
summary: • Extends the term of office for an election commissioner from two years to four years and removes exceptions.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to establish and maintain an electronic military ballot application and transmittal system and provides detailed instructions.
  • Requires each county election board to be able to receive these electronic ballots and applications.
  • Establishes that the electronic filing date will be the date the application or ballot should be considered filed.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to establish and maintain an electronic military ballot application and transmittal system and provides detailed instructions.

name: Enacts the "Modernized voter registration act of New York."
summary:
• Establishes that all qualified individuals will be automatically registered to vote.
  • Lists when a person will be automatically registered to vote.
  • Includes a list of which agencies are "source agencies" and provides criteria for the state board of elections designating additional source agencies.
  • Outlines procedures and requirements for making agreements with source agencies.
  • Outlines procedures for incomplete applications.
  • Outlines procedures for agencies handing and transmitting voter registration information.
  • Provides that the state board of elections will prepare and distribute instructions about program implementation and provides requirements for training.
  • Outlines procedures, guidelines, and requirements for carrying out automatic voter registration.
  • Provides deadlines for creating a format and content of electronic transmissions.
  • Provides that eligible individuals are permitted to register on the day of the election as well as being permitted to register to vote online.
  • Requires the board to make certain information available on the website related to voter registration.
  • Provides procedures and timelines for transmission of online voter registration applications.
  • Requires counties and municipalities to make online services also available through an automated telephone system.
  • Provides guidelines for updating voter registration information online.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Allows election commissioners flexibility to designate how many election inspectors are needed at poll sites.
summary: This bill provides election commissioners flexibility to designate how many election inspectors are needed at poll sites. Nevertheless, each poll site must have a minimum of four election inspectors unless a poll site is located in a district with fewer than one hundred fifty registered voters, in which case there may be a minimum of two election inspectors.

name: Authorizes online facilitation of voter registration.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to provide a secure website for online voter registration.
  • Specifies procedures and requirements.
  • Clarifies that voter data must remain private.
  • Requires the annual report to include the number of voter registration applicants using online systems to register.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
summary:
• Requires county board of elections to mail an absentee ballot with a return postage envelope to every qualified voter in the district. 
  • Provides instruction on the administration of the mailing, timeline, and exceptions.
  • Provides instruction on return of the ballot.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
summary:

  • Provides instruction on the administration of the mailing, timeline, and exceptions.
  • Provides instruction on return of the ballot.

name: Relates to the postmark date for change of enrollment.
summary: This bill allows for a change of enrollment to be received by the Board of Elections showing a dated cancellation mark of the United States Post Office or contained in an envelope showing such a dated cancellation mark which is not later than February fourteenth.

name: Provides that the determination of the board of elections to issue a voter an absentee, military or special ballot shall only be challenged by a judicial proceeding in supreme court and that the board of elections and the voter whose application is challenged shall be necessary parties.
summary:
• Provides that the decision of a board of elections to issue an absentee, military, or special ballot may only be challenged in the New York Supreme Court, with specific timelines and procedures.
  • Specifies reasons a challenge may not be sustained during the canvassing period.

name: Provides that the determination of the board of elections to issue a voter an absentee, military or special ballot shall only be challenged by a judicial proceeding in supreme court and that the board of elections and the voter whose application is challenged shall be necessary parties.

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems
summary: • Eliminates judges from candidates who may run in another party's primary election.

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems
summary: • Eliminates judges from candidates who may run in another party's primary election.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide a return postage guaranteed envelope with absentee ballots.
summary: • Requires a return postage guaranteed envelope be mailed with an absentee ballot.

name: Relates to voting rights including voter protection, voter's bill of rights, illegal voter suppression and intimidation, vote dilution, and preclearance.
summary:
• Provides that a person is guilty of voter intimidation under specific circumstances, listing the circumstances.
  • Requires a Voter's Bill of Rights be posted at each poling place and distributed with official sample ballots.
  • Furnishes the language for the Voter's Bill of Rights and requires it in other languages in certain circumstances.
  • Requires the Board to create a manual of uniform polling place procedures and for local election officials to implement it and ensure that it is available.
  • Includes information to be included in the manual.
  • Clarifies what illegal voter suppression includes and includes penalties.
  • Establishes what constitutes vote dilution.
  • Outlines when pre clearance is required and outlines procedures.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to instant run-off elections in the city of New York for any city-wide elections for the office of mayor, public advocate or comptroller.
summary: This bill requires that New York city-wide primary elections for the office of mayor, public advocate, or comptroller, in which more than two candidates appear on the ballot for the same office, be conducted by instant run-off voting. The bill defines "instant run-off voting" to mean an election in which voters may rank up to five candidates in order of preference, first, second and so on, and in which tabulation proceeds in up to two rounds as follows: If the candidate with the most votes receives a vote total less than fifty percent plus one vote, the two candidates with the most votes proceed to a second round of ballot counting. In the second round, each ballot is counted as a vote for whichever of the two advancing candidates is ranked higher by that voter. Any ballot that does not rank either of the two advancing candidates would not be counted in the second round. The candidate with the most votes in the second round is then declared the winner. The bill requires the portion of the ballot pertaining to elections conducted by instant run-off voting allow a voter to rank candidates in order of choice in a way that is clear and easy to understand and include the opportunity to rank no more than one write-in candidate. The bill also requires ballots be designed so that a voter may mark their first choice in the same manner as for offices not elected by instant run-off voting.

name: Relates to the number of signatures needed for designating petitions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer.

summary: This bill stipulates that the signature requirement for petitions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer is to be reduced by one-quarter, rounded down to the nearest whole number. For designating petitions for political subdivisions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer, except for the position of member of the ward, town, city or county committee, such petitions must be signed by not less than three and three-quarters per 100 residents, as determined by the preceding enrollment, of the then enrolled voters of the party residing within the political unit in which the office or position is to be voted for, excluding voters in inactive status.

summary: This bill establishes portable polling locations for early voting and provides that a county board of elections may establish one or more portable polling locations. The bill requires that designation and location of any portable polling place be made no later than fourteen days before an election. Locations for portable polling locations must take into consideration population density, travel time to the polling place, proximity to other early voting poll sites, public transportation routes, commuter traffic patterns and such other factors the board of elections deems appropriate. Locations for portable polling locations for early voting shall be operational for no fewer than three consecutive days. No portable polling location for early voting established by this subdivision shall replace or otherwise decrease the number of polling places for early voting required by subdivision two of this section.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
summary:
• Provides that nonpartisan election monitors may be appointed by a civic organization or ballot issue committee.
  • Allows for two monitors per polling place by each organization.
  • Provides rules for filing, including rules for the filing statement, and a filing deadline.
  • Clarifies when and how the board of elections may deny a request for nonpartisan election monitors.
  • Creates timelines and guidelines for processing such requests.
  • Outlines credential identification requirements for poll watchers and the content of the credential badge.
  • Outlines rules of who may be appointed a watcher and what watchers may do at the polls. 
  • Provides for substitution of poll monitors.
  • Outlines rules for the number of watchers at a polling place.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Allows photographs of one's self and one's own ballot while voting.
summary:
• Allows voters to photograph only themselves while voting.
  • Provides a misdemeanor offense for someone who forces an individual to photograph and/or post their ballot, or themselves voting, on social media.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: • Requires a candidate's written acceptance within ten days of the filing of a designating petition for a party position for county committee in a city with more than one million residents.

name: Requires voting machines or systems approved by the state board of elections to: permit a voter to review their marked paper ballot; retain such ballot for the purposes of a manual audit; and count only a voter's handmade mark except when certain accessibility exceptions apply.
summary: This bill requires voting machines or systems approved by the Board of Elections to permit a voter to review their marked paper ballot, retain ballots for the purposes of a manual audit, and count only a voter's handmade mark.

name: Relates to the acceptance of nominations for office or for a party position and the constitutional and statutory requirements for such office or position.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill requires that nominees for office affirm they are a citizen of the State of New York, eligible to be elected to the office or position they are nominated for, and, if elected will meet the constitutional or statutory qualifications thereof or, with respect to judicial office, will meet such qualifications within thirty days of the commencement of the term of such office.

name: Reduces the number of signatures required for designating and nominating petitions to one and one half per centum or thirty percent of the signature threshold numbers required by law.
summary: This bill reduces the number of signatures required for designating and nominating petitions to 1.5 per centum or 30% of the signature threshold, whichever is less.

name: Relates to Eastchester fire district elections; follows provisions of election law instead of town law for elections.
summary:
• Provides that elections in the Eastchester Fire District will take place on the Tuesday following the first Monday in November.
  • Requires candidates for Eastchester Fire District to file with the Westchester County board of elections.
  • Provides rules for filling vacancies in the Eastchester Fire District.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provides for the state board of elections to prepare and distribute to each voter a ballot pamphlet for every general election; provides for contents thereof and makes numerous related provisions including the distribution of information relating to each ballot proposal that is submitted to a statewide vote at such general election; permits any person eligible to vote on any ballot proposal to institute a proceeding as to the factual accuracy of statements or constitutional amendments.
summary:
• Describes the purpose for creating a ballot pamphlet and requires the state board of elections to develop and prepare ballot pamphlets.
  • Outlines what must be included in the ballot pamphlet and timelines.
  • Outlines requirements for a committee that will develop materials for the ballot pamphlet.
  • Provides notification requirements.
  • Provides guidelines for the committee accepting and rejecting submissions.
  • Outlines state immunity with respect to the ballot pamphlet.
  • Outlines printing and distribution guidelines.
  • Outlines guidelines regarding proceedings as to the factual accuracy of information in the ballot pamphlet.
  • Adds five copies of each ballot pamphlet to the list of items the board of elections must provide each county.

name: Provides for the state board of elections to prepare and distribute to each voter a ballot pamphlet for every general election; provides for contents thereof and makes numerous related provisions including the distribution of information relating to each ballot proposal that is submitted to a statewide vote at such general election; permits any person eligible to vote on any ballot proposal to institute a proceeding as to the factual accuracy of statements or constitutional amendments.
summary:
• Describes the purpose for creating a ballot pamphlet and requires the state board of elections to develop and prepare ballot pamphlets.
