name: Provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Election dates and administrative deadlines
summary: • Provides that candidates whose party filed to designate more than one person for an office may file a certificate of acceptance or declination by the seventh day after the primary election (for all other candidates it is four days).

name: Provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Election dates and administrative deadlines
summary: • Provides that candidates whose party filed to designate more than one person for an office may file a certificate of acceptance or declination by the seventh day after the primary election (for all other candidates it is four days).

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems
summary: • Eliminates judges from candidates who may run in another party's primary election.

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems
summary: • Eliminates judges from candidates who may run in another party's primary election.

name: Directs the state board of elections to create a plan to permit voting by mail in the event of a natural disaster or state of emergency.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to create a plan for voting by mail when there is a natural disaster or state of emergency. 
  • Defines "voting by mail."
  • Requires the plan be completed by September 1, 2021, or 30 days after passage of the act.

name: Directs the state board of elections to create a plan to permit voting by mail in the event of a natural disaster or state of emergency.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to create a plan for voting by mail when there is a natural disaster or state of emergency. 
  • Defines "voting by mail."
  • Requires the plan be completed by September 1, 2021, or 30 days after passage of the act.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to establish and maintain an electronic military ballot application and transmittal system and provides detailed instructions.
  • Requires each county election board to be able to receive these electronic ballots and applications.
  • Establishes that the electronic filing date will be the date the application or ballot should be considered filed.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to establish and maintain an electronic military ballot application and transmittal system and provides detailed instructions.
  • Requires each county election board to be able to receive these electronic ballots and applications.
  • Establishes that the electronic filing date will be the date the application or ballot should be considered filed.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary:
• Directs each electoral college elector to cast their vote for president and Vice President for candidates nominated by the political party that nominated the elector.
  • Establishes that refusal will constitute a resignation and the vote will not be recorded, and a replacement will be named.
  • Requires ballots used by the elector to bear their name.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary:
• Directs each electoral college elector to cast their vote for president and Vice President for candidates nominated by the political party that nominated the elector.
  • Establishes that refusal will constitute a resignation and the vote will not be recorded, and a replacement will be named.
  • Requires ballots used by the elector to bear their name.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.
summary:
• Prohibits actions creating a conflict of interest for board of election employees including: investing in a company providing services to a candidate in that district, or investing in a company who is a vendor selling voting equipment.
  • Provides penalties.
  • Prohibits a board of elections employee from working for a candidate or being a candidate in the district holding the election.
  • Provides related "leave without pay" policies.
  • Provides that a candidate employed by the board of elections who is not running in a primary election may remain on the payroll for up to 90 days before the general election.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes election commissioners' terms of office from two to four years beginning February 15, instead of January 1, and removes provisions allowing county legislative bodies to do otherwise.
  • Allows county committees to recommend at least two additional people for appointment for commissioner of elections when there is a vacancy and the legislative body failed to appoint someone.
  • Provides instructions for removal of election commissioners and filling vacancies.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes election commissioners' terms of office from two to four years beginning February 15, instead of January 1, and removes provisions allowing county legislative bodies to do otherwise.
  • Allows county committees to recommend at least two additional people for appointment for commissioner of elections when there is a vacancy and the legislative body failed to appoint someone.
  • Provides instructions for removal of election commissioners and filling vacancies.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary: • Prohibits public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as an early voting location, with an additional provision for school buildings without instructional space.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary: • Prohibits public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as an early voting location, with an additional provision for school buildings without instructional space.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
summary:
• Allows certain groups to appoint up to two nonpartisan poll monitors per polling place.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for designating nonpartisan poll monitors, including authorizations, denials, and appeals.
  • Outlines polling place procedures for nonpartisan poll monitors.
  • Outlines the qualifications needed to be appointed a nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Provides the job responsibilities of the nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Provides for credentials for the nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Specifies that there will be no more than two nonpartisan poll monitors from any organization at a polling place at the same time and procedures for if there is more than one organization at the polling place.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.

name: Requires that candidates for certain offices be residents and registered voters in the district containing the public office or party position sought at certain times during the electoral process.
summary:
• Outlines residency requirements for candidates, including allowing localities to enact stricter requirements.
  • Specifies that a candidate for county committee must only be a resident of the Assembly district containing the election district.
  • Specifies candidates must be residents in the district by the time of the party caucus.
  • Specifies that failure to meet residency requirements renders a nomination void.
  • Exempts candidates for Congress, state assembly, state senate or judicial candidates for the Supreme Court from the specified district residency requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires that candidates for certain offices be residents and registered voters in the district containing the public office or party position sought at certain times during the electoral process.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.
summary:
• Requires a risk limiting audit after an election that includes a hand review of at least 3% of paper records.
  • Requires the board of elections to audit 3% of voting machine records.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules to implement risk limiting audit procedures.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.

name: Authorizes additional days of voting as a result of emergencies; includes state of emergency.
summary:
• Adds a state of emergency to the list of reasons a county board of elections may consider for adding an additional day of voting.
  • Provides that notification must be given a week before the additional day of voting and specifies how the notification should be given.
  • Provides that a board of elections may change the date of a party caucus under certain circumstances and outlines guidelines and requirements for the change.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary:
• Allows the option of using the highest number of votes for president in the last election, in addition to the option of using the highest number of votes for governor, when determining the order of candidates on a ballot.
  • Provides rules regarding number of delegates at a judicial district convention for newly formed political parties.
  • Provides rules regarding selecting election district delegates by county committee for newly formed political parties.
  • Adds the office of US President to the list of offices where a nominated candidate my appear multiple times on the ballot.
  • Provides rules for newly formed political parties regarding casting votes at the state committee for presidential electors.
  • Adds presidential electors to the list of offices the board of elections needs to transmit to the state board after a canvass.

name: Establishes provisions requiring absentee ballots that do not have postmarked dates that are received in the mail by the board of elections within three days following the day of election to be cast and counted.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: • Requires an absentee ballot without any date markings indicating when it was mailed to be counted if it arrives to the board of elections by three days after the election.

name: Establishes provisions requiring absentee ballots that do not have postmarked dates that are received in the mail by the board of elections within three days following the day of election to be cast and counted.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: • Requires an absentee ballot without any date markings indicating when it was mailed to be counted if it arrives to the board of elections by three days after the election.

name: Decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) for year two thousand twenty-one.
summary: • Provides that the number of signatures required on designating petitions and independent nominations for those diagnosed with COVID-19 will be reduced by one-third.

name: Decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) for year two thousand twenty-one.
summary: • Provides that the number of signatures required on designating petitions and independent nominations for those diagnosed with COVID-19 will be reduced by one-third.

name: Relates to the crimes of fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus or convention, and criminal impersonation in the first degree where a person pretends to be an elected official or candidate for an elected office and acts by impersonating such an elected official, or candidate or campaign for such an elected office, by communication by internet website or electronic means, with intent to obtain a benefit or injure or defraud another; requires social media companies to establish practi
summary:
• Adds impersonating an election office, candidate, or campaign to the list of crimes of fraud.
  • Lists what is considered fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus, or convention and establishes that the state board of elections has the authority to impose civil penalties on these violations.
  • Furnishes the state board of elections with the authority to seek injunctive relief, and investigative authority including subpoena powers, in cases of impersonation of an election official and other fraud.
  • Requires social media companies to close accounts within 24 hours where they receive complaints alleging first degree criminal impersonation or fraud.

name: Relates to voting rights expansion, voter registration on election day, expansion of the use of and requirements for absentee voting, creation of a real-time statewide voter registration database, special ballots for election employees, and voter affidavits.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Allows qualified individuals to register to vote on Election Day and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows any voter to vote absentee and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows voters to have their absentee ballot mailed to an address other than their permanent address and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows hospitalized veterans to receive their absentee ballot at the address where they are registered to vote.
  • Provides that the board of inspectors will deliver absentee ballots to residents of certain facilities.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create a single official computerized statewide voter registration database within one year and provides associated guidelines and requirements.
  • Provides that absent proof of fraud, special ballots will be presumed valid and will be cast.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: • Provides that anyone who does not have the right to vote, or the right to register to vote, by the state constitution, also does not have the right to vote, or register to vote, locally.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.

name: Requires the election of fire district commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members.
summary:
• Provides that election of fire district members will occur on the same date, and at the same location, as election of school board members in the municipality.
  • Requires that the Secretary of State of the fire district get approval of the board of elections to prepare ballots for the fire district elections.
  • Changes the opening hour for poll openings for the fire district elections from 6:00PM to 6:00AM.
  • Provides that all electoral procedures related to the fire district election will follow the same procedures as the school board elections.
  • Provides that costs for the election will be borne by the fire district.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires the election of fire district commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members.

  • Provides that all electoral procedures related to the fire district election will follow the same procedures as the school board elections.
  • Provides that costs for the election will be borne by the fire district.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relating to requests for absentee ballots.
summary: •  Changes the timespan for receiving absentee ballot applications from 7-30 days before the elections, to a simple deadline of 7 days before the election.

name: Relating to requests for absentee ballots.
summary: •  Changes the timespan for receiving absentee ballot applications from 7-30 days before the elections, to a simple deadline of 7 days before the election.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: • Provides that in presidential election years an additional primary will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (was the first Tuesday in February).

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: • Provides that in presidential election years an additional primary will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (was the first Tuesday in February).

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary: • Requires that elections for municipal office in New York City be "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting systems.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary: • Requires that elections for municipal office in New York City be "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting systems.

name: Requires the board of elections in the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in a ranked choice election, even if a single candidate received a majority of highest rank votes and the tabulation process was not triggered.
summary: • Requires the board of election in New York City to release data on how voters ranked all candidates when using ranked choice voting.

name: Requires the board of elections in the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in a ranked choice election, even if a single candidate received a majority of highest rank votes and the tabulation process was not triggered.
summary: • Requires the board of election in New York City to release data on how voters ranked all candidates when using ranked choice voting.

name: Requires the disclosure of the applicant's social security number when registering to vote on an application for a motor vehicle driver's license.
summary:
• Requires a voter registration applicant to provide his or her social security number.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Prohibits level two or three sex offenders from voting at a school or facility for children.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Provides criminal penalties for a person for unlawfully entering or remaining in a school for the purpose of voting, if they are a sex offender.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires the board of elections, 60 days before each election, to compile a list of registered sex offenders entitled to receive a ballot and send an absentee ballot to each person.
  • Provides that no poll worker will be liable for refusing admittance to a sex offender when they are acting in good faith.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary:
• Prohibits a public school building with instructional space from being used as an early polling location.
  • Allows a public school building with no instructional space to be designated as an early polling location, but gives the superintendent a right to decline the designation.

name: Relates to the number and location of early voting poll sites in certain counties.
summary:
• Increases the maximum number of early voting polling places in a county from seven to ten.
  • Provides that in counties with a population of 1,250,000 or more, but outside cities with a population of one million or more, each town and city should have at least one polling place.

name: Makes provisions relating to the joint nomination of candidates for the offices of governor and lieutenant governor; provides candidates be designated jointly either by the state committee or by petition; provides said petition will be valid only if it jointly designates both candidates.
summary: • Provides that candidates for governor and lieutenant governor will be designated jointly on a petition and on a ballot.

name: Creates a pilot program to provide for an instant runoff voting method to be used in up to ten local governments, selected by the state board of elections, in election years 2024 and 2025; requires report to state legislature.
summary:
• Proposes a pilot program using ranked choice voting in 2024 and 2025 in certain local government elections.
  • Defines ranked choice voting and local government.
  • Provides that the state board of elections will choose 10 pilot locations each year.
  • Requires specific rules for the format of the ballot in ranked choice voting. 
  • Outlines rules for determining a winner in ranked choice voting.
  • Requires the board of elections to conduct a voter education campaign in selected areas about ranked choice voting.
  • Subjects all ranked choice voting elections to existing election laws.

name: Allows a U.S. citizen, who is seventeen years of age, to vote in a primary election, including presidential, if he or she will turn eighteen by the date of the corresponding general election.
summary: • Codifies that seventeen-year-olds who will be eighteen at the time of the general election may vote in the associated primary election.

name: Relates to the registration status of voters; establishes additional requirements for the cancellation of a voter's registration and allows voters who have an inactive status to have their registration returned to active status and to have their vote counted for the election in which they vote.
summary:
• Classifies as misconduct an election official canceling a voter's registration in violation of existing code, or refusing to allow a voter with inactive status to vote.
  • Requires the board of elections to verify a voter's registration before canceling it.
  • Provides procedures for distributing the inactive poll ledger.
  • Provides that if a voter casts a ballot in an affidavit envelope meeting all requirements, the voter is restored to active status.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to nominations for public office without designation.
summary: • Clarifies that an existing code regarding people being nominated for public office at a primary election includes contested and uncontested primaries.

name: Establishes a deadline for changing the location of a polling place for early voting by requiring that no location change may occur within forty-eight hours of the commencement of an early voting period.
summary:
• Requires notice be given to voters at least five days before a voting period if the location of an early voting polling place changes.
  • Provides that if the change is within five days of the beginning of voting, then notice must be given as soon as possible.
  • Prohibits a change within 48 hours of the start of voting.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: • Prohibits a county, city, town, or village from amending a municipal charter, or passing a local law, to allow or to prohibit someone from registering to vote.

name: Provides that casting and canvassing of absentee, military, special presidential, special federal and other special ballots shall occur as such ballots are received by the board of elections.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Special election procedures,Counting and canvassing procedures,Military/UOCAVA voting
summary:
• Allows the board of elections to establish a procedure providing for casting and canvassing ballots, and eliminates specific time deadlines.
  • Requires the board of elections to notify a voter whose absentee ballot was rejected or challenged and give the person an opportunity to correct an error prior to the election.
  • Specifies that if a voters name shows that the voter already voted before Election Day, the voter may only vote by affidavit ballot on Election Day.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes the term of election commissioner from two years to four years, to begin February 15 of the first alternate odd numbered year.
  • Eliminates permissions allowing the county legislative body to determine the length of an election commissioner's term.
  • Changes rules regarding appointment of an election commissioner when an appointment is not forthcoming from the legislative body.
  • Outlines rules for removing an election commissioner.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Prohibits the at large election of any member of the governing or legislative body of a town or village by electors of such town or village; requires the election of such members by wards; repeals certain provisions related thereto.
summary:
• Requires the board of trustees of villages to provide for the election of trustees by ward or alter ward boundaries.
  • Prohibits members of town or village governing or legislative bodies from being elected on an at-large system.
  • Requires the county board of elections to divide each town or village into wards, with specifications about the number and the procedure.
  • Requires all wards to be reapportioned at the same time as congressional, assembly, and senate districts are reapportioned.
  • Outlines procedures in case of delay in setting up the ward system.
  • Directs the attorney general to submit reports to the governor and legislature about towns and villages granted exemptions on April 1, 2024, 2025 and 2026, with specific information requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Removes the requirement that party emblems be included in ballot design.
summary: • Removes reference to an emblem on existing election code regarding ballots, political parties, and nominating petitions.

name: Relates to the time period during which absentee ballots shall be mailed or delivered after an application for such ballot is received by the board of elections.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary: • Provides timelines for mailing absentee ballots based on when an application was received.

name: Relates to designating early polling places.
summary:
• Removes the provision that polling places may not be locations that hold a license to see alcohol for consumption in the premises.
  • Prohibits public school buildings from being designated early polling locations.
  • Allows buildings receiving more than $1 million in annual state grant funding to be used as polling places, with some exceptions.

name: Requires audits by hand recount of voter verifiable audit records.
summary: This bill requires that audits be completed by hand recount.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary: This bill establishes a military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot online. The bill requires each board of elections maintain a system capable of receiving and processing military ballot applications and marked military ballot information, including digital signatures, from the electronic voter registration transmittal system established by the state board of elections. The bill defines "digital signature" as a certificate-based digital identification code issued to qualified personnel by the United States department of defense as part of the common access card or its successor.

name: Includes a statement on the envelopes of ballots for absentee voters and special presidential voters for signature affirmation.
summary: This bill inserts a statement on the envelopes of ballots for absentee voters and special presidential voters for signature affirmation. The bill requires the following added to the envelope: IMPORTANT TO ABSENTEE VOTER: YOU MUST SIGN THE AFFIRMATION ON THIS ENVELOPE and IMPORTANT TO SPECIAL PRESIDENTIAL VOTER: YOU MUST SIGN THE AFFIRMATION ON THIS ENVELOPE.

name: Authorizes, under certain circumstances, full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located.
summary: This bill authorizes full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located provided he or she: (1) is registered to vote; (2) holds no elective office; (3) is not a candidate for any public office to be voted for by the voters of the district in which he or she is to serve, and is not the spouse, parent or child of such a candidate; and (4) is able to speak and read the English language and write it legibly. The bill defines "full-time" as any matriculated student enrolled in at least twelve credit hours per semester at a New York college or university.

name: Provides that qualified persons who have never previously registered to vote in this state may apply personally for registration by appearing at the appropriate polling place for the election district in which such person resides on the day such polling place is open for voting; requires establishment of a procedure to enable such registrants to cast their votes at the appropriate polling places.
summary: This bill provides that qualified persons who have never previously registered to vote may apply for registration by appearing at the appropriate polling place for the election district in which they reside on the day that polling place is open for voting.

name: Provides all registered voters on the day of the general election and the primary election in every even numbered year a full work day off without the loss of pay; provides a tax credit to small businesses who provide a paid day off to employees on general election day.
summary: This bill provides that all registered voters on the day of the general election and the primary election in every even numbered year receive a full work day off without the loss of pay and provides a tax credit to small businesses who provide a paid day off to employees on general election day.

name: Requires at-large electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state; requires congressional electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates who received the highest number of votes in each congressional district; removes and replaces electors who fail to vote in such manner.
summary: This bill provides that Electoral College votes be designated proportionally to the presidential and vice presidential candidate who obtain the greatest number of votes in each congressional district. The bill also creates a pledge that electors must attest to ensuring that their vote is representative of the vote of the district that they represent as an elector and outlines the cause for removal of an elector should they violate the pledge to remain faithful to the voters of the district they represent.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary: • Requires electoral college members to cast a ballot for the candidates nominated by the political party and outlines consequences for refusing to do so.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: Specifies that in years when a presidential and vice-presidential candidate will be elected, an additional primary election will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (a change from the first Tuesday in February).

name: Relates to the use of voting systems by municipalities; provides for the determination of actual expenses of the board.
summary:
• Changes the term voting machine to the term voting system.
  • Requires, when possible for certain local and special districts to use the board of election's voting system for elections and prohibits to board to charge more than the actual expense.

name: Relates to pre-recorded political messages; prohibits automatic dialing-announcing devices unless a live operator provides certain information in the first thirty seconds; requires registration; authorizes attorney general to investigate violations.
summary: This bill prohibits any person or political committee from delivering or knowingly causing to be delivered via automatic dialing-announcing device a pre-recorded political message unless a live operator provides, within the first thirty seconds of the message the name of the candidate or of any organization or organizations the person is calling on behalf of and the name of the person or organization paying for the delivery of the message and the name of the treasurer of any such committee. The bill requires a copy of all scripts and schedules of such calls to be filed with the New York state board of elections  within twenty-four hours of such calls being made. Any person or political committee operating an automatic dialing-announcing device or placing any consumer telephone calls or pre-recorded political messages must register with the secretary of state as well as the New York state board of elections. The bill empowers the attorney general with the power to investigate violations of the bill, including the ability to subpoena records in furtherance of any investigation. Violations of this bill are punishable by a civil fine not to exceed two thousand dollars per occurrence.

name: Requires the board of elections to establish an electronic system allowing absentee voters to monitor the status of their ballot and to correct an unaccepted ballot.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to provide confirmation of receipt of an absentee ballot and information on its acceptance.
  • Requires the board to provide documentation when a ballot is not accepted including the reason it was not accepted.

name: Relates to annual reports of the boards of elections; requires such reports be made available on the boards' websites; requires that the reports include specific performance metrics.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections annual reports to be made public on a website by five days after the report is delivered.
  • Outlines a list of metrics required in the annual report.

name: Relates to the text of proposed constitutional amendments and questions.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to publish the text of each amendment, proposition, and question.
  • Requires the state board of elections to include a relevant form on their website.
  • Requires the Attorney General to prepare and deliver an abstract of the proposed amendment, proposition, or question at least four months before the election.

name: Makes the following participating agencies for purposes of agency assisted voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools; directs the state board of elections to promulgate rules and regulations for implementation.
summary: • Designates public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools as agencies providing voter registration programs.

name: Makes the following participating agencies for purposes of agency assisted voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools; directs the state board of elections to promulgate rules and regulations for implementation.
summary: • Designates public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools as agencies providing voter registration programs.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary:
• Provides the the city of New York will use instant run-off elections or a ranked choice voting system in elections for municipal office.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary:
• Provides the the city of New York will use instant run-off elections or a ranked choice voting system in elections for municipal office.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to proceedings with respect to designating and nominating petitions.
summary: • Provides the option to hold a proceeding regarding a timely invalidation petition within three business days after the proper service of pleadings.

name: Relates to proceedings with respect to designating and nominating petitions.
summary: • Provides the option to hold a proceeding regarding a timely invalidation petition within three business days after the proper service of pleadings.

name: Provides for voter requests for an absentee ballot from the board of elections by telephone.
summary:
• Adds an option to request an absentee ballot by phone.
  • Specifies that voters requesting an absentee ballot by phone are not required to fill out the application before receiving the ballot.
  • Requires the board of elections to keep a written record of phone requests and allows them to complete the absentee ballot application on behalf of the voter.

name: Provides for voter requests for an absentee ballot from the board of elections by telephone.
summary:
• Adds an option to request an absentee ballot by phone.
  • Specifies that voters requesting an absentee ballot by phone are not required to fill out the application before receiving the ballot.
  • Requires the board of elections to keep a written record of phone requests and allows them to complete the absentee ballot application on behalf of the voter.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots.
summary:
• Provides instructions and timelines for when a board of elections determines an affidavit ballot envelope is incomplete or defective.
  • Provides for how the voter may cure the defect.
  • Provides instruction for what the board may do with the cured envelope, including what to do in the case of an invalidation.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots.
summary:
• Provides instructions and timelines for when a board of elections determines an affidavit ballot envelope is incomplete or defective.
  • Provides for how the voter may cure the defect.
  • Provides instruction for what the board may do with the cured envelope, including what to do in the case of an invalidation.

name: Authorizes party designations and nominations for elections to be made via video teleconference or web conference upon notice to the members of the respective committee and allows certificates of designation or nomination to be executed in separate acts by the signatories.
summary:
• Provides that party designations and nominations, except for a primary election, may be made via audio or web conference with certain notification of members.
  • Outlines guidelines for the notification process and its certification.

name: Provides that certain cities and towns shall have early voting poll sites within their boundaries and, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
summary: • Requires locales with a population between 50,000-100,000 to have at least one early voting polling place situated along public transportation routes if possible.

name: Requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants to attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide certain identifying information; requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.
summary: This bill requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide identifying information. The bill requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.

name: Defines the term "party" as any political organization which at the last preceding election for governor polled at least fifty thousand votes for its candidate for governor.
summary: This bill defines the term "party" as any political organization which at the last preceding election for governor polled at least fifty thousand votes for its candidate for governor.

name: Designates certain university and community college campuses as polling places for early voting.
summary: This bill designates college campuses which are operated by the state  as early voting sites and polling sites. The bill mandates a polling place designated for registrants on such campus shall be at a location approved by such college or university and that any university that has an on campus dormitory must have an early voting site on campus.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots.
summary: This bill stipulates that once a board of elections determines, at or before canvassing, that an affidavit ballot envelope is incomplete or is in any other manner defective, the board must, within one day, send to the affidavit ballot voter's address, a notice explaining the reason for such rejection and the procedure to cure the rejection. The board must also contact the voter by either electronic mail or telephone, if that contact information is available to the board. The voter may then cure the aforesaid defects by filing a duly signed affirmation attesting to the same information required by the affirmation envelope and attesting that the signer of the affirmation is the same person who submitted such affidavit ballot. The board must include a form of such affirmation with the notice to the voter. A cure affirmation shall be filed with the board no later than seven business days after the board's mailing of such curable rejection notice. Provided the board determines that such affirmation addresses the curable defect, the rejected ballot shall be reinstated and duly canvassed. If the board of elections is split as to the sufficiency of the cure affirmation, the envelope must be set aside for three days and then canvassed unless the board is directed otherwise by a court order. When the board of elections invalidates an affidavit ballot and the defect is not curable, the voter must be notified by mail sent within three business days of such rejection.

name: Provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.
summary: This bill provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.

name: Provides for automatic voter registration; and establishes a task force to study and make recommendations on the implementation of such automatic voter registration.
summary:
• Establishes automatic voter registration for qualified individuals who do not decline the option.
  • Establishes the automatic voter registration procedure.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists agencies to be included in automatic voter registration.
  • Allows the state board of elections to designate additional agencies to serve as voter registration sites and provides guidance for the process.
  • Requires the state board of elections to develop certain procedures related to automatic voter registration.
  • Provides guidance regarding seeking citizenship.
  • Requires the state board of elections to issue program implementation instructions and training, with certain requirements.
  • Sets September 1, 2022 as the deadline for source agencies and the state board to enter into an agreement, and full compliance by January 1, 2023.
  • Makes certain exceptions.
  • Makes complying changes.
  • Lists certain requirements for colleges and universities in compliance with source agency rules.
  • Establishes that those affirming they registered with a source agency, but missing information on Election Day, are to be permitted to cast an affidavit ballot and outlines related procedures.
  • Specifies that specific transmitted data should not be considered public record.

name: Relates to providing timely written notice of closed primary party rules to newly registered voters; defines the terms "newly registered voter" and "written notice" and sets out what information the board of elections is required to provide to newly registered voters about closed primaries.
summary: This bill provides to newly registered voters, in a timely manner, an explanation as to what a closed primary election is, how party affiliation is related to said closed primary, and the dates for which they need to enroll in a party, if necessary. The bill defines the term "newly registered voter" means any person in the state of New York who has registered to vote after the effective date of this subdivision. The bill also defines "written notice" as a statement from the commissioner of the state board of elections.

name: Relates to the order in which candidates appear on the ballot; requires that offices shall be listed on the ballot in descending order based on the size of the electorate and requires certain federal offices to be listed before state, county or local offices.
summary: This bill orders candidates on the ballot by precedence: electors for president and vice-president, governor and lieutenant governor, state comptroller, state attorney general, United States senator, house representatives, state senator, member of state assembly.

name: Relates to the procedure for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly occurring in a district consisting of parts of more than one county in a city with a population of one million or more; allows for independent nominating petitions to be presented and provides for a special election to be held forty-five days from the date of the governor making a proclamation for a special election.
summary: This bill provides that in a city with a population of one million or more, a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly occurring in a district consisting of parts of more than one county and required to be filled at the next general election shall be filled by popular election. Within three days of the occurrence of such a vacancy, the governor shall make proclamation of a special non-partisan election to fill the office, specifying the district and/or counties in which the election is to be held, and held forty-five days from the date of the proclamation. (b) All nominations for elections to fill vacancies held pursuant to this bill are to be by independent nominating petition, which are required to contain a designated number of signatures the lesser of five percent of votes cast in the last preceding gubernatorial election or one thousand five hundred signatures per petition for the office of state senator and seven hundred fifty signatures per petition for the office of member of assembly and filed within fifteen days after the date of the governor's proclamation. A person elected to fill such a vacancy shall take office immediately upon qualification and serve for the remainder of the unexpired term.

name: Requires at least one form of electronic means to verify voter registration at every polling place.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Voter registration
summary: This bill requires at least one form of electronic means to verify voter registration at every polling place.

name: Relates to requests for proposals for voting machines and contracts for the purchase of voting machines or systems.
summary: This bill provides that any commissioner of the state board of elections may examine voter machines and systems and may solicit requests for proposals for voting machines or systems to be certified by such board for use in New York state. All such requests for proposals shall contain a provision stating that any person or entity submitting a proposal shall pay to the board a fee equal to the cost of such examination.

name: Adds a voter's e-mail address and telephone number to the information contained on a voter registration application that is not available for public inspection.
summary: This bill adds a voter's e-mail address and telephone number to the information contained on a voter registration application that is not available for public inspection.

name: Requires the preparation of reports on assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks.
summary: This bill requires any county board of elections appointing election coordinators and, in the city of New York, the board of elections of the city of New York, must prepare a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks, and specifically enumerate the poll sites for which election inspectors or poll clerks have not yet been assigned while detailing the efforts made to date to fill those assignments. These reports must be filed with the state board of elections no later than one month prior to the election at which election coordinators, election inspectors, and poll clerks are to be assigned.

name: Requires a valid government issued photo identification card be presented when casting a ballot; provides for persons eligible for Medicaid to receive identification cards.
summary: This bill requires a valid government issued photo identification card to be presented when casting a ballot. This bill stipulates the following as valid forms of identification: a New York state driver's license or non-driver ID; a United States passport; an identification card issued by a United States educational institution; a United States military identification card; a government issued medical card or any identification card issued by the United States or the state of New York. Further, this bill mandates that any adult citizen whose income qualifies him or her for Medicaid, as verified in writing by the county's department of social services, is not required to pay any fee for a state-issued identification card.

name: Enacts the "Modernized voter registration act of New York."
summary:
• Establishes automatic voter registration for qualified individuals who do not decline the option.
  • Establishes the automatic voter registration procedure.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists agencies to be included in automatic voter registration.
  • Allows the state board of elections to designate additional agencies to serve as voter registration sites and provides guidance for the process.
  • Requires the state board of elections to develop certain procedures related to automatic voter registration.
  • Provides guidance regarding seeking citizenship.
  • Requires the state board of elections to issue program implementation instructions and training, with certain requirements.
  • Requires the board of elections to offer certain voter registration services on their website and by phone, and provides related procedures.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Relates to promoting inmate voter registration and voting by incarcerated people; requires the department of corrections and community supervision to distribute a voter information guide and hold voter information and registration clinics for incarcerated people every other year.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
• Establishes that incarcerated individuals in a state or local correctional facility are considered residents of the address they had prior to imprisonment.
  • Codifies that a voter's registration will not be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires the establishment of a program to promote voter registration and voting by incarcerated people and outlines what the program should include, and how it should be administered.

name: Relates to requests for proposals for voting machines and contracts for the purchase of voting machines or systems.
summary:
• Provides that any commissioner from the state board of elections may solicit requests for proposals for voting systems to be certified for use in New York.
  • Provides requirements for the request for proposals.
  • Lengthens the amount of time the vendor must provide assistance in training and operating the equipment from five to ten years.
  • Lengthens the amount of time the vendor must keep the machines in good working order from five to ten years.

name: Establishes an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system through which voters may apply for and submit an absentee ballot online.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Cybersecurity
summary: This bill establishes an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system through which voters may apply for and submit an absentee ballot online.

name: Provides a write-in ballot cast in a party primary resulting from the filing of a valid opportunity to ballot petition for a candidate not enrolled in such party shall be void and not counted; makes related provisions.
categories: Ballot access for parties,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Specifies that party members voting in a nomination election or primary election may write in the name of a candidate enrolled in the party.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying updates.
  • Specifies that a write-in ballot cast in a party primary for someone not enrolled in the party will be void.

name: Provides that a person designated as a candidate for two or more party nominations for an office to be filled at the time of a general election who is not nominated at a primary election by one or more such parties may decline the nomination of one or more parties not later than ten days after the primary election.
summary: This bill provides that if a person designated as a candidate for two or more party nominations for an office filled at a general election who is not nominated at a primary election by one or more parties may decline the nomination of one or more parties no later than ten days after the primary election.

name: Relates to the confidentiality of registration records for victims of domestic violence; requires victims of domestic violence wishing to make their registration records confidential to deliver a signed written statement swearing or affirming that they are victims of domestic violence and due to the threat of physical or emotional harm they wish to keep their registration record confidential.
summary:
• Establishes that a registered domestic violence victim may request to keep their voter registration record confidential. 
  • Provides that a new application must be made every four years.

name: Relates to the canvassing of absentee, military and special ballots and ballots cast in affidavit envelopes.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,Provisional ballots,Military/UOCAVA voting
summary:
• Outlines the process and timeline for canvassing absentee, military, and specials ballots, and ballots in affidavit envelopes.
  • Outlines procedures for if there is more than one ballot in an envelope.
  • Outlines procedures for when the validity of a ballot is in question.
  • Outlines procedures for curing a ballot and what to do when a ballot cannot be cured.
  • Establishes procedures for handling federal write in absentee ballots.
  • Establishes procedures for casting and canvassing all valid ballots.
  • Establishes procedures for post-election review and canvassing of affidavit ballots.
  • Establishes procedures for post-election review of invalid absentee, military, and special ballots.
  • Provides powers and duties for the state board of elections in canvassing absentee, military, and special ballots, and affidavit ballots.
  • Adds a requirement to audit the central count ballot scanners and the procedure and timeline.
  • Directs that if a voter appears in the ledger as having been issued an absentee, military, or special ballot, the voter is not permitted to vote by machine on Election Day, but may vote by affidavit ballot.
  • Prohibits courts from altering the schedule of procedures and requires courts to ensure "strict and uniform" application of the election law.
  • Outlines how a candidate may seek and order for for changing the schedule for the canvassing law.

name: Enacts the "Make Voting Easy Act"; requires the board of elections to designate a number of early voting polling places based on the number of registered voters in each county; relates to the hours polls are open for early voting.
summary:
• Establishes that the largest city or municipality in a county must have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
  • Establishes the required number of early voting places in a county based upon population size.
  • Requires that early voting polls be open for at least eight hours (changed from five hours) and changes the closing time to 8:00PM (from 6:00PM) on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays during early voting.

name: Provides for online and in-person instruction and examination of election inspectors, poll clerks and election coordinators.
summary:
• Clarifies that yearly election training may be done in-person or online, with specific requirements.
  • Provides that some trainees may beed to supplement online instruction with in-person instruction.
  • Outlines requirements for notification about training.
  • Directs that exams related to online training should be given both online and in-person, with some exceptions.
  • Adds coordinators to the list of those required to take the exam.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to the mailing and receipt of absentee ballots; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
summary:
• Removes an exception for canvassing absentee ballots without certain verifications when canvassing all other ballots.
  • Changes the deadline for witness signature on various types of absentee ballots to Election Day, instead of the day before the election.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary: • Requires the development and administration of a program to notify voters of changes due to redistricting, and includes specific guidelines.

name: Relates to electronic applications for absentee ballots; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
summary: • Allows for absentee ballot applications to be submitted electronically through a web portal or by email.

name: Establishes an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system through which voters may apply for and submit an absentee ballot online.
summary:
• Adds an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system to the options for a voter to order an absentee ballot.
  • Provides submission deadlines.
  • Provides that the state board of elections must establish and maintain an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system.
  • Outlines procedures for transmitting information to local boards.
  • Outlines guidelines for submitting an electronic request for an absentee ballot.
  • Outlines required procedures for completing and processing an electronic request.
  • Outlines procedures for if a signature is missing on the request.

name: Increases the number of registrants an election district may contain with the approval of the county board of elections; increases number on county committee.
summary:
• Changes the maximum number of registered voters in an election district, with approval by the county board of elections, from 1,150 to 2,000.
  • Removes the allowed maximum number of political party members in a county committee.

name: Relates to the definition of the term "name" for purposes of designating or nominating a candidate for public office or party position.
summary: This bill defines the term "name" for purposes of designating or nominating a candidate for public office or party position means an individual's formal name or an alternate, anglicized, or familiar form of a name or nickname, notwithstanding the candidate's proper name as it appears on his or her voter registration form, provided that such name is demonstrated to be commonly used to identify the candidate in the candidate's community, does not include a descriptive term, and further provided that the use of such name is not intended to mislead or confuse potential signatories, and would not tend to confuse or mislead potential signatories, as to the candidate's identity.

name: Authorizes a change of location of early voting polling places for certain special, primary and run-off primary elections when no voters of the municipality with the highest population within the county are eligible to vote.
categories: Special election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Provides that the board of elections may have an early voting polling place in the municipality with the highest population in the county where eligible voters will vote in the election.

name: Amends the constitution to delete the requirement that registration for purposes of voting be completed at least ten days before election day and provides that laws be made to adequately safeguard against deception in the exercise of the right of suffrage.
summary: • Amends the constitution by removing the requirement that voter registration be completed ten days before an election.

name: Authorizes ballot by mail by removing cause for absentee ballot voting.
summary: This constitutional amendment removes the need for cause in absentee voting.

name: Amends the constitution to delete the requirement that registration for purposes of voting be completed at least ten days before election day and provides that laws be made to adequately safeguard against deception in the exercise of the right of suffrage.
categories: Election dates and administrative deadlines,Voter registration
summary: • Removes the requirement that registration must be completed ten days before each election from the Constitution.

name: Authorizes ballot by mail by removing cause for absentee ballot voting.
summary: This constitutional amendment removes the need for cause in order to vote absentee.

name: Relates to absentee voting by residents of nursing homes and other long-term care facilities; provides that inspectors of the board of elections shall not physically deliver ballots to residents of such facilities.
summary:
• Prohibits inspectors of the board from visiting certain facilities, or delivering ballots to residents of facilities for elections held before December 1, 2021.
  • Requires boards of elections to mail or deliver absentee ballots to voters in facilities in the same way they deliver absentee ballots to other absentee voters.

name: Relates to the number of signatures of enrolled voters needed on a designating petition for any town office to be filled by all the voters of certain towns and the number of signatures required on a designating petition for a village election; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: • Provides the required number of signatures for a designating petition in towns with less than 100,000 residents.

name: Relates to voting and registration for voting by formerly incarcerated individuals convicted of a felony.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
• Provides that those convicted of a felony and sentenced to prison, or who are serving time for a felony, may not register to vote.
  • Requires courts to advise those pleading guilty to a felony that conviction will result in the loss of the right to vote while in prison, and that the right to vote will be restored when released from the correctional facility.
  • Requires inmates to be notified verbally and in writing upon release about restoration of their right to vote. 
  • Requires inmates to be offered a voter registration form and assistance in completing it, and provides guidance on where and how to submit the form.
  • Requires that individuals serving a period of community supervision be notified verbally and in writing about the right to vote, along with additional related instructions.
  • Requires the implementation of an educational program related to the above provisions.
  • Provides conforming changes.

name: Relates to absentee voting application deadlines; all applications requesting an absentee ballot by mail must be received by the board of elections no later than the fifteenth day before the election for a ballot is first requested; applications delivered in person shall be received no later than the day before such election.
summary: This bill changes absentee voting application deadlines. The bill provides all applications requesting an absentee ballot by mail must be received by the board of elections no later than the fifteenth day before the election. The bill also mandates applications delivered in person be received no later than the day before the election.

name: Requires the county seat in Washington county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: • Specifies that Washington County must have at least one polling place available for early voting.

name: Relates to the number of state senators and inclusion of incarcerated persons in the federal census for population determination for redistricting purposes and to the functioning of the independent redistricting commission in the determination of district lines for congressional and state legislative offices.
categories: Redistricting,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Requires incarcerated people to be included in census numbers for determining districts.
  • Moves the timeframe for submission of a redistricting plan earlier from January 1-15 in a year ending in two, to November 1-15 in a year ending in one.
  • Changes the deadline for notification of disapproval of apply from February 28 to January 1.
  • Changes deadlines for submission for the year 2022 only.
  • Specifies incarcerated people should be included in their address of last residence.
  • Changes the number of state senators from 50 to 63.
  • Requires the ratio for apportioning senators be divided by 63 rather than 50.
  • Changes procedures for approving redistricting plans.
  • Removes language excluding aliens in redistricting census counts.
  • Provides clarifying edits.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for the prior election; provides for a permanent absentee ballot application list.
summary:
• Provides that a board of elections will send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an application for the previous election.
  • Requires a board of elections to create a permanent absentee ballot application list and allows voters to request to be removed from the list.

name: Decreases the number of signatures for independent nominating petitions of candidates for public office; now 2.5%.
summary: This bill lowers the number of signatures for independent nominating petitions to 2.5% of the total number of votes cast for governor at the last gubernatorial election, excluding blank and void votes, not to exceed 1,750 signatures.

name: Removes the option to file an opportunity to ballot petition in the June 2021 primary election.
summary: This bill removes the option to file a ballot petition in the June 2021 primary election.

name: Permits county committees to amend their rules to permit committee members whose terms are expiring in 2021 to remain in their office for an additional one-year term.
summary: This bill permits county committees to amend their rules to permit committee members whose terms are expiring in 2021 to remain in their office for an additional one-year term.

name: Relates to the automatic voter registration process; amends certain voter registration processes and the agencies to be included as designated agencies.
summary:
• Provides that if an applicant at the Department of Motor Vehicles does not check the box declining to be registered to vote, then they are giving consent to register.
  • Provides clarifying edits to the instructions on the application.
  • Provides effective dates for certain sections of existing code.
  • Removes and adds certain agencies from the list of agencies offering voter registration.
  • Provides that the governor will conduct a review of participating agencies every other year, instead of every year.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Changes the title of the related election code.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Reduces the number of signatures for designating petitions; provides dates for the signing and filing of designating petitions in 2021.
summary:
• Reduces the percentage of voters required to sign a designating petition from 5% of enrolled party voters to 1.5%.
  • Makes exceptions for various offices filled by voters of the city of New York and surrounding boroughs, where it decreases requirements for each office individually.

name: Relates to the number of state senators and inclusion of incarcerated persons in the federal census for population determination for redistricting purposes and to the functioning of the independent redistricting commission in the determination of district lines for congressional and state legislative offices.
categories: Redistricting,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Amends the number of state senators from 50 to 63.
  • Provides that if a census fails to count incarcerated people, the appropriate state entities will provide the correct information by September 1 of the year ending in one.
  • Changes the deadline for submission of a redistricting plan from January 1-15, in a year ending in two, to November 1-15, in a year ending in one.
  • Provides that if a second redistricting plan is needed, it must be submitted by January 1, instead of February 28.
  • Provides exceptions for redistricting plan deadlines in 2022.
  • Requires that incarcerated people by counted in their last place of residence.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Creates a pilot program to provide for an instant runoff voting method to be used in up to ten local governments, selected by the state board of elections, in election years 2024 and 2025; requires report to state legislature.
summary:
• Establishes a pilot ranked choice voting system.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires that ten counties be chosen in 2024 and ten in 2025 to implement the ranked choice pilot program for local offices.
  • Establishes procedures for selection.  
  • Provides instruction for ranked choice ballot format and administration of the ballot.
  • Establishes procedures for counting ballots.
  • Requires education of voters, through certain means, about ranked choice voting.
  • Subjects all ranked choice voting elections to existing applicable election laws.

name: Requires the boards of elections to provide a secure website or web portal through which voters can track their absentee application or absentee ballot.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to create a secure website where voters may submit an absentee ballot application.
  • Requires website tracking of the absentee ballot request and the ballot.
  • Prohibits the website to require creation of an account.

name: Relates to the confidentiality of registration records for victims of domestic violence; requires victims of domestic violence wishing to make their registration records confidential to deliver a signed written statement swearing or affirming that they are victims of domestic violence and due to the threat of physical or emotional harm they wish to keep their registration record confidential.
summary:
• Provides that a victim of domestic violence may complete a written statement wishing their registration record be kept confidential.
  • Requires the board of elections to ensure that it be kept confidential.

name: CA: Prohibit local government from allowing non-electors to vote
summary: This bill prohibits non-electors from voting in state or local elections.

name: Revise voter registration and conduct of elections
Enact Ohio Election Security and Modernization Act
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Drop-box availability,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Early voting administration,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Ballot collection,Testing and certification
summary:
• Requires the Secretary of State to implement an Automated Voter Registration and Verification System not later than two years after the bill takes effect.
  • Requires that, when a person applies to receive or renew a driver’s license or state identification (ID) card in person at the Bureau of Motor Vehicles (BMV), the Registrar or deputy registrar must follow a process to obtain the person’s identifying information and confirm whether the person is registered to vote under the person’s current name and address.
  • Requires the Registrar or deputy registrar, if the person is not registered to vote or is registered but has had a change of name, to offer the person an opportunity to register using a customer-facing electronic display, unless the Registrar or deputy registrar has information indicating that the person is not eligible to vote in Ohio.
  • Requires the Secretary and the Registrar jointly to prescribe procedures to offer voter registration when a customer renews a driver’s license or state ID card online through  the BMV, which will be available beginning July 1, 2022.
  • Requires the BMV, if a customer has had a change of address, to automatically transmit the person’s current information, along with any phone number or email address the person has provided, to the Secretary.
  • Requires that when a BMV customer applies for or renews a driver’s license or state ID card, and the person’s voter registration is already up to date, the Registrar or deputy registrar must notify the Secretary so that the transaction can be noted in the person’s registration record.
  • Specifies procedures for the Secretary to process voter registration information received from the BMV and send it on to the appropriate board of elections.
  • Specifies procedures for the board of elections to process voter registration information received from the Secretary.
  • Requires the board, when registering a person or updating the person’s registration, to send the person a modified notice of voter registration that includes the process to decline the registration or update.
  • Allows the person to decline the registration or update by signing and returning the notice.
  • Requires the board to correct an elector’s registration if the elector’s name or address is updated in error, and the elector requests a correction and provides identification.
  • Specifies that if the error is not corrected before Election Day, the elector may cast a provisional ballot using the elector’s true name and address and have the ballot counted.
